title: ~게 되다 [ge doeda] (End up doing)
short_explanation: Used to express events or actions that occur unintentionally or as a result of another event or circumstance.
long_explanation: '~게 되다 [ge doeda]' is a grammar point in Korean used to indicate outcomes that are primarily out of the speaker's control, often unexpected or resulted due to certain circumstances or events. It conveys the sense of 'end up doing' or 'come to do' in English. It is used to express a change or transition, the result of an event, or to describe the inevitable outcome of a certain situation.

examples.kr: 시험 공부를 하다가 잠이 들어서 결국은 벼락치기를 하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom gongbureul hadaga jami deureoseo gyeolgugeun byeorakchigireul hage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep while studying for the exam, and ended up cramming at the last minute.

examples.kr: 팀원들이 모두 바빠서 저 혼자 발표 준비를 다 하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Timweondeuli modu bappaseo jeo honja balpyo junbireul da hage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: All team members were busy, so I ended up preparing the presentation all by myself.

examples.kr: 지갑을 잃어버려서 엄마에게 돈을 빌려야 하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Jigabeul ilheobeoryeoseo eommaege doneul billyeoya hage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: I lost my wallet, so I ended up having to borrow money from my mother.

examples.kr: 티켓이 매진되어 결국은 그 콘서트를 보지 못하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Tiket-i maejin doeeo gyeolgug-eun geu konsoteu leul boji mothage doeeotseoyo.
examples.en: The tickets sold out, so I ended up not being able to see that concert.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (Make/let someone do)
short_explanation: This is a way to indicate that you are making or allowing someone else do something.
long_explanation: `~게 하다 [ge hada]` is a Korean grammar form used to express that someone is making or allowing someone else to do something. This structure often indicates a persuading, ordering, permitting, or causing action to happen. In English, it's similar to the expressions 'make someone do something' or 'let someone do something'.

examples.kr: 엄마는 저를 매일 한 시간 동안 피아노를 연습하게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun jeoreul maeil han shigan dongan pianoreul yeonseuphage haesseoyo.
examples.en: My mother made me practice the piano for an hour every day.

examples.kr: 선생님은 학생들이 공부하게 했는데, 그것이 좋은 성적을 받을 수 있는 유일한 방법이라고 생각했어요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun hagsaengdeul-i gongbu hage haessneunde, geugeos-i joheun seongjeog-eul bad-eul su issneun yuilhan bangbeob-ilago saeng-gaghaess-eoyo.
examples.en: The teacher made the students study, thinking that it was the only way to get good grades.

examples.kr: 아버지는 저를 이 일에 대해 생각하게 했습니다, 이 일은 중요한 결정을 필요로 하고 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Abeojineun jeoreul i ire daehae saenggakhage haessseubnida, i ireun jung-yohan gyeoljeong-eul piryo-ro hago isseossseubnida.
examples.en: My father made me think about this matter, it required an important decision.

examples.kr: 나는 내 친구에게 서울에 간다고 말하게 했습니다, 그는 그 정보를 알아야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun nae chingu-ege seoul-e gandago mal hage haessseubnida, geuneun geu jeongbo-reul al-a-ya haessseubnida.
examples.en: I made my friend say that he is going to Seoul, he needed to know that information.

title: ~고 싶다 [go sipda] (Want to do)
short_explanation: Used to express a desire or a wish.
long_explanation: '~고 싶다 [go sipda]' is a grammatical form used to express a person's desire or wish to do something in the Korean language. It's often used when you are expressing that you want to do an action and is typically used with verbs. It is the equivalent of 'I want to ~' or 'I would like to ~' in English. Note that this form is often personal and should be used primarily in situations where you are expressing your own desires, not the desires of others.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 듣고 싶어요, 그러니까 한국어 노래를 틀어주세요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangug-eo leul deudgo sip-eoyo, geuleonikka hangug-eo nolaereul teul-eojuseyo.
examples.en: I want to listen to Korean, so please play some Korean songs.

examples.kr: 방학에는 친구들과 여행 가고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Banghag-eneun chingu-deulgwa yeohaeng gago sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to go on a trip with my friends during the holidays.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 한국어를 가르치고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-ege hangugeo leul galeuchigo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to teach her Korean.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 만들고 싶어서 요리 수업을 듣고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Masissneun eumsig-eul mandeulgo sip-eoseo yoli sueob-eul deudgo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to make delicious food, so I want to take cooking classes.

title: ~기 전에 [gi jeone] (Before doing)
short_explanation: Used to express 'before doing something'.
long_explanation: '~기 전에 [gi jeone]' is a grammatical structure in Korean used for expressing an action that occurs prior to another action, essentially meaning 'before doing something'. It is a way to indicate that one action happens before another action and is usually used with a verb in order to describe a chronological sequence of events in the past, present, or future.
formation: Verb in Dictionary form + 기 + 전에

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 가기 전에 항상 아침 식사를 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe gagi jeone hangsang achim siksa reul habnida.
examples.en: I always have breakfast before going to school.

examples.kr: 출발하기 전에 자세히 계획을 세우는 것이 중요합니다.
examples.romaji: Chulbalhagi jeone jasehi gyehoegeul seweuneun geosi junghabnida.
examples.en: It's important to plan carefully before leaving.

examples.kr: 제가 카페에 가기 전에 당신의 주문을 알려주십시오.
examples.romaji: Jega kapee gagi jeone dangsinui jumuneul allyeojusipsio.
examples.en: Let me know your order before I go to the cafe.

examples.kr: 시험을 치르기 전에, 그 주제에 대해 충분히 공부를 해야합니다.
examples.romaji: Sihumeul chirugi jeone, geu jujee daehae chungbunhi gongbureul haeyahabnida.
examples.en: Before taking the test, you must study enough about that topic.

title: ~기 때문에 [gi ttaemune] (Because of doing)
short_explanation: Used to express a reason or cause; 'because of doing'.
long_explanation: '기 때문에 [gi ttaemune]' is a grammar point used in Korean to express a reason or cause related to an action, which is equivalent to 'because of doing' in English. This form is composed of the nominalizing suffix '기' attached to a verb stem, then followed by '때문에' which functions as a connecting ending meaning 'because'. It's typically used to explain the cause-effect relationship between two actions or situations.

examples.kr: 저는 공부하기 때문에 친구들과 놀러 갈 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbuhagi ttaemune chingudeulgwa nolleo gal sigani eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because I study, I have no time to hang out with my friends.

examples.kr: 감기에 걸리기 때문에 학교에 가지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Gamgie geolligi ttaemune hakgyoe gaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I couldn't go to school because of catching a cold.

examples.kr: 많은 돈을 벌기 때문에 직장에 계속 나가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Maneun doneul beolgi ttaemune jikjange gyesok nagago isseoyo.
examples.en: I keep going to work because I earn a lot of money.

examples.kr: 운동하기 때문에 건강해지고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undonghagi ttaemune geonganghaejigo isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm getting healthier because of exercising.

title: ~기로 하다 [giro hada] (Decide to do)
short_explanation: Used to express making a decision or a plan to do something.
long_explanation: '~기로 하다' is generally used in the form of Verb + 기로 하다 to express a decision or planning to do something. It can be translated as 'decide to do'. It is generally used to share a decision made in the past, the outcome of a conversion or a mutual agreement.
formation: Verb in 한자(韓字) Stem + 기로 하다

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 오후에 만나기로 했어요. 그래서 내일 아침에 일어나서 준비해야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil ohue mannagiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo naeil achime ileonaseo junbihaeya dwaeyo.
examples.en: We decided to meet tomorrow afternoon. So I have to wake up and get ready in the morning tomorrow.

examples.kr: 저는 다음 주에 친구와 여행가기로 했어요. 그래서 이번 주말에 가방을 싸야 돼요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun daeum jue chinguwa yeohaenggagiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo ibeon jumare gabaengeul ssaya dwaeyo.
examples.en: I decided to go on a trip with a friend next week. So I have to pack my bag this weekend.

examples.kr: 최근에 너무 많이 먹어서 다이어트하기로 했어요. 그래서 오늘부터 식단을 조절하려고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Choegeneun neomu mani meogeoseo daieoteugiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo oneulbuteo sikdaneul jojeolharyeogo haesseoyo.
examples.en: I ate too much recently, so I decided to go on a diet. So I tried to control my diet from today.

examples.kr: 시험 공부를 시작하기로 했어요. 그래서 오늘부터 매일 노트를 작성하고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom gongbureul sijakgigiro haesseoyo. Geuraeseo oneulbuteo maeil noteureul jaksseunghago sippeoyo.
examples.en: I decided to start studying for the test. So I want to write notes every day from today.

title: ~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada] (Start to do)
short_explanation: Expresses the commencement of an action or event, equivalent to 'start to do' in English.
long_explanation: '~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada]' is used in Korean to express the initiation or commencement of an action. By attaching the nominalization marker '~기' to a verb followed by the verb '시작하다 (to start)', you can express the beginning of the action executed by the verb. It implies that an action or event has just begun or is about to start in the near future.

examples.kr: 날씨가 점점 따뜻해지면서 꽃들이 피기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga jeomjeom ttatteuthaejimyeonseo kkotdeuri pigi sijakhayeo.
examples.en: As the weather started to get warmer, the flowers started to bloom.

examples.kr: 학기가 시작되자마자 숙제를 하기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgiga sijakdoejamaja sujereul hagi sijakhayeo.
examples.en: As soon as the semester started, I started doing homework.

examples.kr: 그녀는 피아노를 치기 시작했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun piano chigi sijakhaetsseumnida.
examples.en: She started playing the piano.

examples.kr: 친구들이 도착하자마자 파티가 시작하기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeuri dochakhajamaja pati sijakgihagi sijakhayeo.
examples.en: As soon as my friends arrived, the party started.

title: ~기는 하다 [gineun hada] (Do something as a habit)
short_explanation: Used to express that someone does something as a regular activity or habit.
long_explanation: '~기는 하다 [gineun hada]' is a Korean grammar point used to express the habituality of an action, suggesting that someone does something as a regular activity or habit. It's a combination of the nominalizing suffix '~기' and the verb '하다', which is often translated as 'to do'. When this pattern is attached to the base form of action verb, it suggests that the subject of the sentence does that activity routinely or habitually.

examples.kr: 매일 아침에 영어를 공부하기는 하지만, 아직도 버벅거린다.
examples.romaji: Maeil achime yeongeoreul gongbuhagineun hajiman, ajikdo beobeokgeorinda.
examples.en: I study English every morning as a habit, but I'm still struggling.

examples.kr: 저는 주말에 책을 읽기는 하는데, 많은 시간을 할애하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jumare chaegil ilgkineun hande, maneun siganeul haraehajineun anhayo.
examples.en: I do read books on the weekends as a habit, but I don't devote a lot of time to it.

examples.kr: 요리를 만들기는 하지만, 그렇게 제 맛에 들지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul mandeulgineun hajiman, geureoke je mate deuljineun anhayo.
examples.en: I do cook as a habit, but I don't really like the taste.

examples.kr: 운동을 하루에 한 시간씩하기는 하는데, 아직도 체력이 부족해요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul harue han sikanggineun hande, ajikdo cheryeogi bujokaeyo.
examples.en: I do exercise for an hour a day as a habit, but I'm still lacking in stamina.

title: ~는 대로 [neun daero] (As it is)
short_explanation: '~는 대로' is used to state that something is done exactly as it is or as it is told.
long_explanation: The '~는 대로 [neun daero]' structure is used to express a sense of doing something exactly as it is, as it exists or as stated, emphasizing that no alteration, distortion or difference has occurred. It can also suggest that someone is doing or should do things strictly as they were told, hence focusing on following instructions or maintaining the original state of something.

examples.kr: 제가 말하는 대로 정확히 따라해 주세요, 그렇게 하면 실패할 가능성이 낮아질 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Jega malhaneun daero jeonghwakhi ttarahae juseyo, geureohge hamyeon silpaehal ganeungseongi najajil geosibnida.
examples.en: Please follow exactly as I say, doing so will lower the chance of failure.

examples.kr: 이 설명서에 적힌 대로 장난감을 조립하면 어려움 없이 완성할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: I seolmyeongseoe jeoghin daero jangnangameul jo-riphamyeon eoryeoum eobsi wanseonghal su issseubnida.
examples.en: If you assemble the toy as written in these instructions, you can complete it without difficulty.

examples.kr: 그는 부모님이 가르치는 대로 모든 것을 해왔고, 그 노력 덕분에 충분히 성공적인 삶을 살고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun bumonim-i gareuchineun daero modeun geoseul haewatgo, geu noryeok deogbun-e chungbunhi seong-gongjeog-in salm-eul salgo issseubnida.
examples.en: He has done everything as his parents taught him, and thanks to his efforts, he is living a sufficiently successful life.

examples.kr: 음악을 들을 때는 가수가 부르는 대로 따라 부르는게 제일 재미있어요.
examples.romaji: Eumageul deureul ttaeneun gasuga bureuneun daero ttara bureuneunge jeil jaemiisseoyo.
examples.en: When listening to music, it's most fun to sing along just the way the singer does.

title: ~는 바람에 [neun barame] (Because of)
short_explanation: This grammar is used when indicating the cause of a negative result or situation.
long_explanation: The Korean grammatical pattern '~는 바람에 [neun barame]' translates to 'because of' or 'due to'. It's used to indicate the cause or reason behind a negative consequence or situation. Its usage is common in complaints or expression of regret, and it emphasises the negative impact of the cause on the outcome.

examples.kr: 집에 늦게 도착한 바람에 이른 아침 수업을 놓쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe neujge dochakhan barame irun achim sueobeul nohcheosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I arrived home late, I missed the early morning class.

examples.kr: 그녀가 파티에 오지 않은 바람에 기분이 좋지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga pati-e oji anheun barame gibuni jotji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I felt bad because she did not come to the party.

examples.kr: 비가 오는 바람에 피크닉을 취소했어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneun barame pikeunigeul chwisohaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had to cancel the picnic because of the rain.

examples.kr: 전화를 받지 못한 바람에 중요한 미팅을 놓쳤어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonhwareul badji motan barame jungyohan miteingeul nohcheosseoyo.
examples.en: I missed an important meeting because I couldn't answer the phone.

title: ~는 데 [neun de] (But)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~는 데 [neun de]' is a conjunction used in Korean to introduce a clause contrastive or contradictory to the first part of the sentence, akin to 'but' or 'however' in English. It is used to emphasize the contradiction between the two statements or situations, and is often placed between two clauses in a sentence.

examples.kr: 저는 밥을 많이 먹었는 데, 아직도 배가 고파요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun babeul mani meogeotneun de, ajikdo baega gopayo.
examples.en: I ate a lot, but I'm still hungry.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 항상 늦게 잠에 드는 데, 항상 일찍 일어나요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun hangsang neutge jame deuneun de, hangsang iljjik ileonayo.
examples.en: My friend always goes to bed late, but always wakes up early.

examples.kr: 요즘 날씨가 추운 데, 눈이 안 와서 아쉬워요.
examples.romaji: Yojum nalssiga chuneun de, nuni an waseo aswiwoyo.
examples.en: The weather is cold these days, but it's regrettable that it's not snowing.

examples.kr: 영화 보러 갔는 데, 표가 매진이 되어서 보지 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwa boreo gatneun de, pyoga maejini dwaeseo boji mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I went to see a movie, but I couldn't because the tickets were sold out.

title: ~는지 모르다 [neunji moreuda] (Don't know if)
short_explanation: It is used when the speaker is questionable or unsure about the situation or fact.
long_explanation: '~는지 모르다' is a form used to express uncertainty or lack of knowledge about something in Korean. It corresponds to the English 'do not know if'. This construction is used when the speaker does not know whether something happened, exists, or is true. The verb in front of '는지 모르다' must be in the adnominal form.
formation: Verb-는지 모르다 / Verb-ㄴ/은지 모르다 / Adjective-는지 모르다

examples.kr: 그가 오늘 학교에 올 것인지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga oneul hakgyoe ol geotinji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know if he's coming to school today.

examples.kr: 그녀가 어떤 옷을 입을지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga eotteon oseul ibeulji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know what kind of clothes she will wear.

examples.kr: 그가 이 이야기를 들었는지 모릅니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga i iyagireul deureotneunji moreumnida.
examples.en: I don't know if he heard this story.

examples.kr: 우리 친구가 이곳에서 행복할지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Uri chinguga igoseseo haengbokhalji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know if our friend will be happy here.

title: ~는지 알다 [neunji alda] (Know if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'know if' or 'know whether'.
long_explanation: The structure '~는지 알다 [neunji alda]' is used to express the concept of knowing if something is the case or not. It is utilized when conveying what someone knows or doesn't know about a certain aspect or event. The usage of this form often appears in sentences with unknown information about the subject or the situation.

examples.kr: 그가 내 말을 이해하는지 알 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga nae mareul ihaehaneunji al su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know if he understands my words.

examples.kr: 그녀가 결정을 내렸는지 알고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga gyeoljeongeul naeryeonneunji algo sip-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to know if she has made a decision.

examples.kr: 우리가 다음 주에 만날 수 있는지 알아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Uriga da-eum jue mannal su issneunji al-aya haeyo.
examples.en: We need to find out if we can meet next week.

examples.kr: 학생들이 문제를 해결하는지 알기 위해 선생님들이 항상 확인합니다.
examples.romaji: Haksaengdeuli munjeleul haegyeolhaneunji algi wihae seonsaengnimdeuli hangsang hwaginhapnida.
examples.en: Teachers always check to know if the students are solving the problem.

title: ~마다 [mada] (Every)
short_explanation: Used to express the regular occurrence of an action; 'every'.
long_explanation: '~마다 [mada]' is a postposition used in Korean to express a recurring or continuous action that happens at regular intervals, often corresponding to 'every' in English. This grammar point indicates repetition, illustrating that something happens each time or at each occurrence of the mentioned subject or object. It is applied to nouns denoting time, places, or people, to describe a habitual or regular circumstance.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침마다 일찍 일어나서 운동을 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achimmada iljjik ileonaseo undongeul habnida.
examples.en: I wake up early and exercise every morning.

examples.kr: 여행을 갈 때마다 새로운 사람들을 만나서 매우 흥미로워요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul gal ttaemada saeroun saramdeureul mannaseo maeu heungmirowoyo.
examples.en: Whenever I go traveling, meeting new people is always very interesting.

examples.kr: 테스트가 끝날 때마다 휴식을 조금씩 취합니다.
examples.romaji: Testeu-ga kkeutnal ttaemada hyusigeul jogeumssik chwihabnida.
examples.en: I take a bit of a rest every time a test ends.

examples.kr: 일주일마다 한국어를 공부하기 위해 도서관에 갑니다.
examples.romaji: Iljuilmada Hangugeo-reul gongbuhagi wihae doseogwan-e gamnida.
examples.en: I go to the library to study Korean every week.

title: ~부터 ~까지 [buteo ~ kkaji] (From ~ to ~)
short_explanation: This grammar is used to express the beginning and end of an action or a range.
long_explanation: '~부터 ~까지 [buteo ~ kkaji]' is used in Korean to indicate a range, from the starting point to the end point. It can be used to describe periods of time, range of numbers, spaces or locations, or to express the starting and ending point of an action or state. This grammar point can be translated as 'from ~ to ~' in English. It's important to note that the verbs in the sentence referring to this range should be in harmony.
formation: Starting point + 부터 + End point + 까지

examples.kr: 우리는 월요일부터 금요일까지 일해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun wolyoilibuteo geumyoilkkaji ilhaeyo.
examples.en: We work from Monday to Friday.

examples.kr: 점심시간은 오후 12시부터 1시까지에요.
examples.romaji: Jeomsimsiganeun ohu 12sibuteo 1sikkaji eyo.
examples.en: Lunch time is from 12 p.m. to 1. p.m.

examples.kr: 서울부터 부산까지 기차로 얼마나 걸리나요?
examples.romaji: Seoulbuteo Busankkaji gicharo eolmanana geollinayo?
examples.en: How long does it take from Seoul to Busan by train?

examples.kr: 나는 한국어를 공부하기 시작했을때부터 지금까지 많이 발전했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangugeoreul gongbu hagi sijakhaesseulttaebuteo jigeumkkaji mani baljeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I have improved a lot from when I started studying Korean to now.

title: ~아/어/여 보이다 [a/eo/yeo boida] (Seems, looks like)
short_explanation: Used to express that something appears, seems or looks a certain way based on the perception or assessment of the speaker.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~아/어/여 보이다' in Korean is used to express the speaker's perception, conjecture or judgment based on the appearance or situation of something or someone. It can be translated as 'seems' or 'looks like' in English. It is used to demonstrate that the speaker is making an inference or commenting on something based on their own subjective perception, rather than stating an objective fact.

examples.kr: 그 사람은 행복해 보여서 다른 사람들도 기분이 좋아지자나요.
examples.romaji: Geu saram-eun haengbokhae boyeoseo dareun saramdeuldo gibun-i jo-ajijanayo.
examples.en: That person looks happy, making other people feel good too.

examples.kr: 이 음식은 맛있어 보이지만 실제로는 좀 짰어요.
examples.romaji: I eumsik-eun masiss-eo boijiman siljeleoneun jom jjass-eoyo.
examples.en: This food looks tasty, but it's actually a bit salty.

examples.kr: 그 남자는 항상 기분이 나쁘게 보이는데 어떤 문제가 있나요.
examples.romaji: Geu namja-neun hangsang gibun-i nappeuge boineunde eotteon munje-ga issnayo.
examples.en: That man always looks upset, maybe there's a problem.

examples.kr: 이 옷은 사진에서 볼 땐 예뻤는데, 실제로 보니깐 그저 그래 보여요.
examples.romaji: I ot-eun sajin-eseo bol ttaen yeppeossneunde, siljelo bonikkan geujeo geulae boyeoyo.
examples.en: This outfit looked pretty in the photos, but in reality, it just looks so-so.

title: ~아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda] (Do for someone)
short_explanation: This form is used to express the action of doing something for someone.
long_explanation: The '아/어/여 주다 [a/eo/yeo juda]' form is a commonly used sentence ending in Korean that expresses the action of doing something for someone. This grammatical form is often used when the speaker is talking to someone who is doing a favor for them or is willing to do something for them. It's a mood form to express the speaker's gratitude and can also be used when asking someone to do something.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어/여 + 주다 depending on the vowel of the last syllable of the verb stem

examples.kr: 피곤해서 그럼 내가 그 숙제를 해 줄게.
examples.romaji: Pigonsaeseo geureom naega geu sukje reul hae julge.
examples.en: You seem tired, so I'll do your homework for you.

examples.kr: 걱정하지 마세요, 우리 아빠가 우리를 위해 보호해 줄 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geokjeonghaji maseyo, uri appaga urireul wihae boho hae jul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Don't worry, our dad will protect us.

examples.kr: 집에 돌아가는 길에 아빠가 택시를 잡아 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe doraganeun gire appaga taeksi reul jaba jueosseo yo.
examples.en: On the way home, my dad caught a taxi for us.

examples.kr: 나는 어머니에게 저녁식사를 만들어 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eomeoni ege jeonyeoksiksa reul mandeul eo jueo sseo yo.
examples.en: I made dinner for my mother.

title: ~아/어/여야만 하다 [a/eo/yeoyaman hada] (Have to do)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express necessity or obligation; 'have to do', 'must'.
long_explanation: The phrase '~아/어/여야만 하다 [a/eo/yeoyaman hada]' in Korean language is used when someone must do something or has an obligation to do something. It's similar to English expressions such as 'have to', 'need to' or 'must'. It is formed by combining the verb stem with '아/어/여야만 하다', depending on the verb’s final vowel.

examples.kr: 모든 학생들은 시험을 준비해야만 해요, 그렇지 않으면 실패할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Modeun haksaengdeuleun siheomeul junbihaeyaman haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon silpaehal geosibnida.
examples.en: All students have to prepare for the exam, otherwise they will fail.

examples.kr: 지금 당장 나가야만 해요, 만약 늦으면 비행기를 놓칠 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Jigeum dangjang nagayaman haeyo, manyag neujmyeon bihaenggireul nochil geosibnida.
examples.en: I have to leave right now, otherwise I will miss the plane.

examples.kr: 너는 이 일을 마무리해야만 해 서연 집에 갈 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Neoneun i ireul mamurihaeyaman haseo yeon jibe gal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You have to finish this work in order to go home.

examples.kr: 우리는 매일 아침 스트레칭을 해야만 해요, 건강을 유지하기 위해서입니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun maeil achim seuteureching-eul haeyaman haeyo, geongangeul yujihagi wihaeseoibnida.
examples.en: We have to stretch every morning to maintain our health.

title: ~아/어/여도 되다 [a/eo/yeodo doeda] (Is it okay to)
short_explanation: Used to ask or state if it's okay or permissible to do something.
long_explanation: '~아/어/여도 되다 [a/eo/yeodo doeda]' is a commonly used grammar pattern in Korean to ask for or give permission to do something. This pattern is typically found in interrogative (question) sentences or declarative statements signifying 'it is okay to ...' or seeking permission by asking 'can I or may I ...'

examples.kr: 저는 이 자리에 앉아도 되나요? 다른 사람이 예약하지 않았을 경우에만 가능하요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i jarie anjaedo doenayo? Dareun sarami yeyaghaji anhasseul gyeong-uman ganeunghayo.
examples.en: Can I sit in this seat? It's only possible if no one else has reserved it.

examples.kr: 내일 포토샵을 사용해도 돼요? 내 프로젝트에 필요하거든요.
examples.romaji: Naeil photoshopeul sayonghaedo dwaeyo? Nae peurojekteue piryohageodeunyo.
examples.en: Can I use Photoshop tomorrow? It's needed for my project.

examples.kr: 크게 음악을 들어도 되는 곳이 있나요? 록 음악을 좋아해서요.
examples.romaji: Keuge eumageul deureodo doeneun gosi issnayo? Rok eumageul joahaseoyo.
examples.en: Is there a place where I can listen to music loudly? I like rock music.

examples.kr: 나는 비가 와도 축구를 해도 돼요. 저는 비를 매우 좋아해서요.
examples.romaji: Naneun biga wado chukgureul haedo dwaeyo. Jeoneun bireul maeu joahaseoyo.
examples.en: I can play soccer even if it's raining. It's because I love the rain.

title: ~아/어/여서는 안 되다 [a/eo/yeoseoneun an doeda] (Must not)
short_explanation: '~아/어/여서는 안 되다' is a Korean grammar pattern used to indicate that one must not do something.
long_explanation: The Korean language grammar point ~아/어/여서는 안 되다 is used to express prohibition or that something must not be done. The literal translation of this grammar point in English would be 'It must not be done'. It's a straightforward way of telling someone not to do something and you will most commonly hear it in formal or polite scenarios. It follows the verb stem, which transforms based on the vowel sound of the verb’s final syllable.
formation: Verb stem + 아/어/여 + 서는 안 되다

examples.kr: 이 표지판을 보면, 여기에서 담배를 피워서는 안 되어요.
examples.romaji: I pyojipaneul bomyeon, yeogiseo dambaereul piwoseoneun an doeyo.
examples.en: Looking at this sign, you must not smoke here.

examples.kr: 우리는 건강을 소홀히 해서는 안 됩니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun geongangeul soholhi haeseoneun an doeyo.
examples.en: We must not neglect our health.

examples.kr: 이 작업은 정밀하게 해야 해서, 정신없이 해서는 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: I jageobeun jeongmilhage haeya haeseo, jeongsin eobsi haeseoneun an doeyo.
examples.en: This job needs to be done meticulously, it must not be done carelessly.

examples.kr: 듣기 테스트 때문에 핸드폰을 켜서는 안 된다고 강조했습니다.
examples.romaji: Deudgi teseuteu ttaemune haendeuponeul kyeoseoneun an doendago gangjohaetsseumnida.
examples.en: I emphasized that you must not turn on your mobile phone because of the listening test.

title: ~아/어서 [a/eo-seo] (Because, So)
short_explanation: This is used to express cause and effect, or reason and result.
long_explanation: The '~아/어서 [a/eoseo]' form is an important grammatical phrase in Korean, used to express the relationship of cause and effect, or reason and result. It is generally used to indicate the reason or cause for an action or state. There is also a temporal meaning, meaning 'after' or 'when', used to describe doing something after something else.

examples.kr: 오늘은 일이 많아서 학교에 가지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun iri manhaseo haggyoe gaji mothayossuyo.
examples.en: I couldn't go to school today because I had a lot of work.

examples.kr: 방이 춥어서 옷을 더 많이 입었어요.
examples.romaji: Bangi chuwoseo oseul deo mani ibossuyo.
examples.en: I wore more clothes because the room was cold.

examples.kr: 그는 운동을 많이 해서 건강한 몸을 유지하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun undongeul mani aeseo geonganghan momeul yujiha-go isseoyo.
examples.en: He maintains a healthy body because he exercises a lot.

examples.kr: 키가 적어서 외투를 사기 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Kiga jeok-eoseo oetu-reul sagi eolyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I had a hard time buying a coat because of my short stature.

title: ~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon joketda] (I wish/hope)
short_explanation: Used to express a desire for something to happen, equivalent to 'I wish/hope' in English.
long_explanation: '~았/었으면 좋겠다 [at/eosseumyeon joketda]' is a Korean grammar form used to express a wish or hoping for a certain event or situation to happen. This grammar structure combines past tense verb endings with the conditional '면' and '좋겠다' which means 'hope'. The nuance is similar to saying 'I wish' or 'I hope' in English wherein you hope for something that, while not currently true, you desire it to be or become so.

examples.kr: 많은 시간을 가졌으면 좋겠어요, 그럼더 많은 책을 읽을 수 있었을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Manheun siganeul gajosseumyeon jokesseoyo, geureom deo manheun chaegeul ilgul su isseosseul tende.
examples.en: I wish I had more time, then I could have read more books.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 왔으면 좋겠어요, 그래야 우리는 더 시원하게 쉴 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga wasseumyeon joketseoyo, geuraeya urineun deo siwonhage swil su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I hope it rains tomorrow, then we can relax more comfortably.

examples.kr: 그녀는 내 말을 더 이해했으면 좋겠다, 그럼 우리의 서로의 의견을 더 잘 나눌 수 있을 거에요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nae mareul deo ihaehaesseumyeon joketda, geureom urineui seoroui uigongeul deo jal nanul su isseul geoe.
examples.en: I wish she understood my words better, then we could exchange our own opinions better.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 날씨가 좋았으면 좋겠어요, 그럼 피크닉 갈 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumare naghwaga johasseumyeon joketseoyo, geureom picnic gal su isseul geos gatayo.
examples.en: I hope the weather is good this weekend, then it seems we can go on a picnic.

title: ~어/아야 하다 [eo/ayahada] (Have to, should)
short_explanation: Used to express obligation, necessity or compulsion; 'have to', 'should'.
long_explanation: '~어/아야 하다 [eo/ayahada]' is a grammar point in Korean language used to express obligation, necessity, or compulsion, akin to 'have to' or 'should' in English. It is used to denote a task or action that must be performed as a requirement or due to some external pressure or obligation. The verb-ending changes depending on the final vowel of the verb stem. If the final vowel is '아' or '오', '아야 하다' is used otherwise '어야 하다' is used with other vowels.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있으니까 오늘 밤에 공부해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseunikka oneul bame gongbuhayeo haeayo.
examples.en: I have to study tonight because I have an exam tomorrow.

examples.kr: 우리는 이번 주말에 집을 청소해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun ibeon jeumare jibeul cheongsohaeya haeyo.
examples.en: We have to clean the house this weekend.

examples.kr: 네가 감기에 걸렸으니까, 약을 먹어야 하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nega gamgigeollyeosseunikka, yageul meogeoyahagesseoyo.
examples.en: As you have caught a cold, you should take medicine.

examples.kr: 일찍 일어나야 해서 얼른 잠에 들어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Iljjik ileonayeo haseo eolleun jane deuleoya haeyo.
examples.en: As I have to get up early, I should go to sleep quickly.

title: ~어/아도 [eo/ado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if' indicating a condition or assumption.
long_explanation: '~어/아도 [eo/ado]' is a conjunctive form in Korean that is used to express an assumption or a conditional situation that could occur. The suffix '도' carries the meaning of 'even if' or 'although'. The preceding vowels '어/아' are dependent on the verb stem's last vowel, similar to other Korean grammar forms. It essentially allows for the creation of conditional sentences, where the consequence or effects of a hypothetical action or state are discussed. It does not imply a negative connotation and is neutral in tone.
formation: Verb stem + 어/아(If the verb stem final syllable has vowel 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ') + 도

examples.kr: 비가 오더라도 나는 계속 걸어갈 거예요, 그것이 제일 빠른 방법이라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Biga odeorado naneun gyesok georeogal geoyeyo, geugeosi jeil ppareun bangbeobirago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: Even if it rains, I will continue to walk, as I think that is the fastest method.

examples.kr: 피곤하다고 아무리 말해도 저는 계속 일해야 합니다, 이 일을 끝내야 해요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhadago amuri malhaedo jeoneun gyesok ilhaeya habnida, i ireul kkeutnaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if I say I'm tired no matter how much, I must keep working, I need to finish this job.

examples.kr: 어려운 문제라도 저는 포기하지 않고 계속 시도할 거예요, 저는 항상 도전을 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Eoryeoun munjeralado jeoneun pogihaji anhgo gyesok sidohal geoyeyo, jeoneun hangsang dojeoneul joahaeyo.
examples.en: Even if it is a hard question, I won't give up and continue to try, I always like a challenge.

examples.kr: 시험 결과가 좋지 않아도 저는 분발하겠어요, 실패는 성공의 어머니라고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheom gyeolgwaga jojinhaji anhado jeoneun bunbalhagessueyo, silpaeneun seonggongui eomeonirago saenggakhabnida.
examples.en: Even if the test results are not good, I will exert myself, I think failure is the mother of success.

title: ~어/아 버리다 [eo/a beorida] (Regretfully, completely)
short_explanation: Used to express that an action is completed, often with regret or unintended consequences.
long_explanation: '~어/아 버리다 [eo/a beorida]' is a verb ending in Korean that expresses the completion of an action, often with a sense of regret or with unintended results. This grammar point is usually used to highlight situations where the speaker or someone else has done something they didn't intend to do, or wish they hadn't done, leading to regret or a complete change.

examples.kr: 제가 중요한 출장을 놓쳐 버렸어요, 그래서 사장님이 저를 혼냈어요.
examples.romaji: Jega jungyohan chuljangeul nohchyeo beoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo sajangnimi jeoreul honnesseoyo.
examples.en: I regrettably missed an important business trip, so the boss scolded me.

examples.kr: 친구가 제 가방을 다치어 버렸어요, 그래서 제 모든 물건들이 다 쏟아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga je gabangeul dachyeo beoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo je modeun mulgeondeuli da ssodajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend accidentally dropped my bag, so all my belongings spilled out.

examples.kr: 브레이크를 밟지 않으면 차가 충돌해서 모두 상해를 입어 버릴 수도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Beureikeureul balpji anheumyeon chaga chungdolhaeseo modu sanghaereul ibeo beoril sudo isseoyo.
examples.en: If you don't hit the brakes, the car could crash and everyone inside could get completely injured.

examples.kr: 저도 모르게 그 말을 들어 버렸어요, 그래서 제 기분이 매우 나빠졌어요.
examples.romaji: Jeodo moreuge geu mareul deureo beoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo je gibuni maeu nappajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I unintentionally overheard that comment and it completely ruined my mood.

title: ~으면/면 [eumyeon/myeon] (If, when)
short_explanation: Used to express 'if' or 'when' in conditions or hypothetical situations.
long_explanation: '~으면/면 [eumyeon/myeon]' is used in Korean to express conditions or hypothetical situations. This grammar point is equivalent to 'if' or 'when' in English. It is usually used to denote a future possibility, expectation, or plan under the condition that something occurs. This form of the verb stands at the end of the clause, making it a complex form of a sentence.

examples.kr: 비가 오면 우산을 가져와야 해요.
examples.romaji: Biga omyeon usaneul gajyeowaya haeyo.
examples.en: If it rains, you should bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 시간이 있으면 책을 좀 더 읽어 보겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani iss-eumyeon chaeg-eul jom deo ilg-eo bogess-eoyo.
examples.en: If I have time, I will try to read more books.

examples.kr: 영화를 보면 이해가 더 쉬울 거예요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwaleul bomyeon ihaega deo swiul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you watch the movie, you will understand it more easily.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으면 나가서 산책하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Nalssi ga joh-eumyeon nagaseo sanchaekhagessseubnida.
examples.en: If the weather is good, I will go out for a walk.

title: ~을/를 빼다 [eul/reul ppaeda] (Except for)
short_explanation: Used to express 'except for' or 'excluding', conveying an exclusion of something from a group or a set.
long_explanation: The phrase '~을/를 빼다 [eul/reul ppaeda]' is a conjunction used in Korean to imply an exception to the general statement, or to indicate that something is 'not included' or 'excluded'. Therefore, it can be translated as 'except for', 'aside from', or 'discounting' in English. The noun, grouping, or person that we want to make an exception from a group or a set is attached to '~을/를' and '빼다' follows. The sentence '은/는' can be used to describe who or what is included in the group.

examples.kr: 그는 아무 것도 하지 않았어요, 그림 그리는 것을 빼고 말이죠.
examples.romaji: Geuneun amu geotdo haji anhasseoyo, geurim geurineun geoseul ppaego marijyo.
examples.en: He didn't do anything, except for drawing pictures.

examples.kr: 모든 학생들이 방과 후에 운동을 했어요, 제가 아픈 것을 빼고 말이죠.
examples.romaji: Modeun haksaengdeuri banggwa hue undongeul haesseoyo, jegA apeun geoseul ppaego marijyo.
examples.en: All the students exercised after school, except for me being ill.

examples.kr: 저는 모든 과일을 좋아해요, 체리를 빼고 말이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun modeun gwaireul joahaeyo, cherireul ppaego marieyo.
examples.en: I like all fruits, except for cherries.

examples.kr: 지금까지 모든 영화를 다 봤어요, 코메디를 빼고요.
examples.romaji: Jigeumkkaji modeun yeongwareul da bwasseoyo, komedireul ppaegoyo.
examples.en: So far, I've watched all the movies, except for comedies.

title: ~을/를 수 있다 [eul/reul su itda] (Can, possible)
short_explanation: Used to express the ability or possibility to do something; 'can', 'be able to'.
long_explanation: '~을/를 수 있다 [eul/reul su itda]' is a verb ending that indicates the speaker's ability or possibility to perform an action in Korean. The subject of the sentence is capable of doing the action expressed by the verb. This verb ending is often used in both formal and informal language to signify capability or possibility so it can translate to 'can', 'be able to', 'possible' in English.

examples.kr: 우리는 이 문제를 해결할 수 있어요, 모두 함께 협력하면 충분히 가능하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun i munjeleul haegyeolhal su isseoyo, modu hamkke hyeopheoghamyeon chungbunhi ganeunghadago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: We can solve this problem, I think it's perfectly possible if we all work together.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 그 회의에 참석할 수 있을 것 같아요, 다행히 다른 일정이 없어서 참석 가능한 시간이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil geu hoeuie chamseoghal su isseul geos gatayo, dahenghi dareun iljeongi eopseoseo chamseog ganeungnan siganieyo.
examples.en: I think I can attend the meeting tomorrow, luckily I'm free so the time for participation is available.

examples.kr: 당신은 수영을 배우면 언젠가는 자유자재로 수영할 수 있을 거예요, 노력하면 가능합니다.
examples.romaji: Dangshineun suyeongeul baeumyeon eonjenganeun jayujajaero suyeonghal su isseul geoyeyo, noryeoghamyeon ganeunghamnida.
examples.en: If you learn swimming, you'll be able to swim freely someday, it's possible if you try.

examples.kr: 그는 한국어를 열심히 공부하면 TOPIK 시험을 패스할 수 있을 것입니다, 그리고 꼭 성공할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangugereul yeolsimhi gongbuhamyeon TOPIK siheomeul paeseuhal su isseul geosibnida, geurigo ggok seonggonghal geosibnida.
examples.en: If he studies Korean hard, he will be able to pass the TOPIK exam, and he will definitely succeed.

title: ~을/를 통해 [eul/reul tonghae] (Through, via)
short_explanation: Used to express the means, method, or channel through which something is done, achieved, or communicated.
long_explanation: '~을/를 통해 [eul/reul tonghae]' is a postposition used in Korean to show that something is done, achieved, or communicated through a particular method, medium, or channel. It is used to specify the way how something is done, or the conduit through which information or action is transmitted. This grammar point essentially translates to 'through' or 'via' in English, indicating the process or medium involved.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 드라마를 통해 배웠어요, 그래서 의미를 더 잘 이해할 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul deurameul tonghae baeweosseoyo, geuraeseo uimireul deo jal ihaehal su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: I learned Korean through dramas, so I could understand the meanings better.

examples.kr: 우리는 이메일을 통해 회의 일정을 조정했어요, 그래서 시간 관리가 더 효율적이었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun imeireul tonghae hoeui iljeongeul jojeonghaesseoyo, geuraeseo sigan gwanriga deo hyoyuljeogieosseoyo.
examples.en: We adjusted the meeting schedule via email, so time management was more efficient.

examples.kr: 그는 음악을 통해 자신의 감정을 표현하곤 해요, 음악은 그에게 가장 효과적인 소통 방법이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun eumageul tonghae jasinui gamjeongeul pyohyeonghagon haeyo, eumageun geuege gajang hyogwajeogin sotong bangbeobieyo.
examples.en: He often expresses his feelings through music, music is the most effective form of communication for him.

examples.kr: 사진을 통해 우리는 다른 사람들의 일상생활을 이해하고 공감할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sajineul tonghae urineun dareun saramdeuri ilsaenghwareul ihaehago gonggamhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Through photos, we can understand and empathize with other people's daily lives.

title: ~을까 [eulkka] (Shall we?)
short_explanation: Used to make a suggestion or proposal; 'shall we?', 'what about?'.
long_explanation: '~을까 [eulkka]' is a grammar point used in Korean to suggest an idea or action to another person. It is relatively informal and primarily for friendly or casual settings. It is frequently used to ask rhetorical questions to suggest or propose plans or actions. It is similar to 'shall we?' or 'what about?' in English.

examples.kr: 우리 이번 주말에 캠핑을 가볼까?
examples.romaji: Uri ibeon jumal-e kaemping-eul gabolkkah?
examples.en: Shall we go camping this weekend?

examples.kr: 내일 영화를 볼까?
examples.romaji: Naeil yeonghwa-reul bolkkah?
examples.en: Shall we watch a movie tomorrow?

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 식당에서 저녁을 먹을까?
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeok-e sikdang-eseo jeonyeok-eul meogeulkkah?
examples.en: Shall we eat dinner at a restaurant tonight?

examples.kr: 학원 후에 공부를 할까?
examples.romaji: Hakwon hu-e gongbu-reul halkkah?
examples.en: Shall we study after going to the academy?

title: ~을래 [eullae] (Want to)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker's intention or will; 'want to'.
long_explanation: '~을래 [eullae]' is a sentence ending in Korean, used when the speaker wants to express his or her own intention or will to do something. It also implies a suggestion and can be translated as 'want to' in English. It's often used in informal speech between friends or close acquaintances.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 밤 영화보러 갈래, 너도 같이 가고 싶어?
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul bam yeonghwaboreo gallae, neodo gachi gago sip-eo?
examples.en: I want to go to watch a movie tonight, do you want to go with me?

examples.kr: 저는 집에서 저녁을 먹을래, 외식하기보다 집에서 먹는 음식이 더 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jib-eseo jeonyeog-mogeullae, oesik-hagiboda jib-eseo meokneun eumsigi deo joahyo.
examples.en: I want to eat dinner at home, I prefer home-cooked meals over eating out.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 주말에 친구들과 등산을 갈래, 건강을 위해 운동을 좀 해야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon jumale chingudeulgwa deungsaneul gallae, geongangeul wihae undongeul jom haeya hal geot gat-ayo.
examples.en: I want to go hiking with my friends this weekend, I think I need to do some exercise for my health.

examples.kr: 나는 내일부터 다이어트를 시작할래, 최근에 좀 살이 찐 것 같아서요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeilbuteo daieoteu-reul sijak-hallae, choegeune jom sal-i jjin geot gataseoyo.
examples.en: I want to start a diet from tomorrow, I think I've gained some weight recently.

title: ~을지라도 [euljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'Even if', indicating that regardless of the condition, the following statement holds true.
long_explanation: '~을지라도 [euljirado]' is a conjunctive ending in Korean which means 'even if'. This is usually used to indicate that regardless of the condition stated by the clause ending in '을지라도', the following clause still holds true. In other words, it underlines that the action or state in the main clause will take place irrespective of the circumstances specified in the subordinate clause.

examples.kr: 문제가 어려울지라도 포기하지 마세요, 결국에는 해결할 수 있을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Munjega eoryeouljirado pogihaji maseyo, gyeolgugen haegyeolhal su isseul geosibnida.
examples.en: Even if the problem is difficult, don't give up, you will eventually be able to solve it.

examples.kr: 이 책이 비싸길지라도 꼭 필요해서 반드시 사야겠어요.
examples.romaji: I chaegi bissagiljirado ggok piryohaseo bandeusi saya gessoyo.
examples.en: Even if this book is expensive, I have to buy it because I really need it.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려울지라도 열심히 공부하면 분명 성과가 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeouljirado yeolsimhi gongbuhamyun bunmyeong seonggaga isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Even if the test is difficult, if you study hard, there will surely be results.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추울지라도 친구들과 약속이 있어서 외출해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chwiuljirado chingudeulgwa yaksogi isseoseo oechulhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if the weather is cold, I have to go out because I have a promise with friends.

title: ~을지언정 [euljieonjeong] (Whether...or...)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'whether...or...', expressing a condition or possibility.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~을지언정 [euljieonjeong]' is used in Korean to present two possible scenarios or conditions. It translates to 'whether...or...' in English. This form is commonly used to express an uncertain situation where both options hold a possibility, or to emphasize that no matter what the condition might be, the result will be unchanged.

examples.kr: 시험에 떨어질지언정 목표를 향해 노력하는 것이 중요합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheome tteoreojiljieonjeong mokpyoreul hyanghae noryeokhaneun geosi jungyohabnida.
examples.en: Whether you fail the exam or not, it's important to strive towards your goal.

examples.kr: 벌써 봄이 왔을지언정 아직 추운 날씨예요.
examples.romaji: Beolsseo bomi wasseuljieonjeong ajik chuun nalssiyeoyo.
examples.en: Whether spring has already come, the weather is still cold.

examples.kr: 방이 클지언정 정리하지 않으면 엉망이 될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Bangi keuljieonjeong jeongrihaji anheumyeon eongmangi doel geosibnida.
examples.en: Whether the room is big or not, it will be a mess if you don't tidy it up.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 전화 할지언정 그녀가 받을지 안 받을지는 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege jeonhwa haljieonjeong geunyeoga badeulji an badeuljineun moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: Whether I call her or not, I don't know if she will answer.

title: ~이 되다 [i doeda] (Become)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a change or transformation; 'become'
long_explanation: '~이 되다 [i doeda]' is a common expression in Korean that is used to demonstrate the transformation or change from one state or condition to another, often referring, but not limited, to changes in weather, job positions, relationships, behaviour, or a particular state. The expression '이 되다' is typically used after a noun.

examples.kr: 가을이라서 날씨가 추워지니까 점점 니트웨어가 필요하다는 것을 느끼게 되어요.
examples.romaji: Ga-eul-iraseo nalssi-ga chuwo-jini-kka jeomjeom nit-wea-ga pilyohan geot-eul neukkige doeeoyo.
examples.en: As it becomes autumn and the weather gets colder, I start to feel the need for knitwear.

examples.kr: 학부생 때는 지망 직업이 변호사였는데, 대학원에서는 교수가 되고 싶다는 생각이 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Hakbosaeng ttaeneun jimang jig-eob-i byeonhosa-yeossneunde, daehakwon-eseoneun gyosu-ga doego sipda-neun saeng-gag-i deuleosseoyo.
examples.en: When I was an undergraduate, I aspired to be a lawyer, but in graduate school, I started to think of becoming a professor.

examples.kr: 나는 친구들과 공부를 함께하니까 점점 좋은 학생이 되어가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Na-neun chingu-deul-gwa gongbu-reul hamkke-hanikka jeomjeom joeun haksaeng-i doeeo-gago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I am becoming a better student as I study with my friends.

examples.kr: 얼굴에 흠집이 난 후에, 그 흠집은 큰 흉터가 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Eolgul-e heumjip-i nan hu-e, geu heumjip-eun keun hyungteo-ga doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: After the face was scratched, that scratch became a big scar.

title: ~이나 ~ [ina] (Either, or)
short_explanation: Used to provide options or alternatives; 'either', 'or'.
long_explanation: '~이나 ~ [ina]' is used in Korean to provide alternatives or options between subjects or objects. It's akin to 'either' or 'or' in English. It's commonly used in sentences to express uncertainty or indecision, where more than one choice is available. Note that the first instance of '이나' is attached directly to the end of a word, while the second '나' is usually followed by a verb or adjective.

examples.kr: 우리는 주말에 영화를 보러 가거나, 또는 집에서 게임이나 할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Urineun jumal-e yeonghwareul boreo gageona, tto-neun jib-eseo gaeimirado hal geos-ida.
examples.en: We are either going to go watch a movie on the weekend, or might play some games at home.

examples.kr: 커피나 차나 마시러 가고 싶습니다.
examples.romaji: Keopina chana masireo gago sipseubnida.
examples.en: I want to go for either coffee or tea.

examples.kr: 오늘이나 내일이나 언제나 돼.
examples.romaji: Oneulina naeuirina eonjena dwae.
examples.en: Either today or tomorrow, anytime is fine.

examples.kr: 이번 달에는 여행을 가거나, 또는 집에서 책이나 읽을 계획이다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon dar-eneun yeohaengeul gageona, tto-neun jib-eseo chaegina ilgeun gyehoeg-ida.
examples.en: This month, I am planning to either go on a trip, or read books at home.

title: ~이라도 [irado] (At least)
short_explanation: Used to express 'at least', 'even if', or 'even'.
long_explanation: '~이라도 [irado]' is used in Korean to convey a meaning of the least favorable option or an alternative under a certain condition, similar to 'at least' or 'even if' in English. It allows the speaker to reduce the degree of a certain expectation or to express a minimal request when there seems to be no other options.

examples.kr: 이 비싼 가격에도 불구하고, 저기 있는 음식이라도 사먹어야겠어요. 제가 아무것도 먹지 않으면 아무런 힘이 없을 테니까요.
examples.romaji: I bissan gagyeogedo bulguhago, jeogi inneun eumsigirado sameogeoya getsseoyo. Jega amugeotdo meokji an-eumyeon amuron himi eobs-eul tenikka yo.
examples.en: Even though it's expensive, I must at least buy and eat the food over there. If I don't eat anything, I won't have any energy.

examples.kr: 오늘의 일정이 아주 바쁜데, 저녁이라도 제대로 먹어야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneulyi iljeongi aju bappeunde, jeonyeogirado jedaero meogeoya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: Today's schedule is very busy, but I think I should at least have a proper dinner.

examples.kr: 그의 성격이 별로지만, 일이라도 잘해서 팀에서 중요한 사람이에요.
examples.romaji: Geuui seonggyeogi byeollojiman, irirado jalhaeseo timeseo jungyohan sarameyo.
examples.en: Even though his personality is not great, he does his work well so he is an important person in the team.

examples.kr: 이번 시험이 어렵다고들 하지만, 돌아가는 이라도 따라가야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomi eoryeobdagodeul hajiman, doraganeun irado ddaragayagesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though they say this exam is difficult, I should at least follow what's going on.

title: ~이랑 [irang] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to express ', and' or ', with' when connecting two or more nouns.
long_explanation: '~이랑 [irang]' is a common conjunction used in Korean to connect two or more nouns, similar to 'and' or 'with' in English. It is often used in everyday spoken language, making it quite informal. It can be used to introduce people, things, or ideas, or to list items or actions in sequence.

examples.kr: 제가 오늘 친구이랑 영화를 보러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Jega oneul chingu irang yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to see a movie with a friend today.

examples.kr: 저는 커피이랑 케이크를 주문했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopi irang keikeu reul jumunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I ordered coffee and cake.

examples.kr: 언니이랑 나는 같은 옷을 입었어요.
examples.romaji: Eonnirang naneun gateun otseul ibeosseoyo.
examples.en: My sister and I wore the same clothes.

examples.kr: 아빠이랑 엄마는 서울에 살아요.
examples.romaji: Appa irang eommaneun seoul-e sal-ayo.
examples.en: My dad and mom live in Seoul.

title: ~이래 [irae] (Since)
short_explanation: Used to express a certain period of time from a past point to the present; 'since'.
long_explanation: '~이래 [irae]' is a connector used in Korean to express a duration of time from a certain past point or event until the present moment. It is similar to the concept of 'since' in English, marking a starting point in the past from which a condition or event has continued. It should be used with a verb in pasttense that signifies a specific past event or point in time.

examples.kr: 제가 태어난 이래 가장 추운 겨울이었어요, 이렇게 추운 날씨를 경험한 적이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jega taeeonan irae gajang chuun gyeouliyeosseoyo, ireohge chuun nalssireul gyeongheomhan jeogi eopseoyo.
examples.en: It was the coldest winter since I was born, I have never experienced such cold weather.

examples.kr: 그가 학교를 졸업한 이래로 처음으로 그를 다시 만났어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga hakgyoreul joleobhan iraero cheoeumeuro geureul dasi mannasseoyo.
examples.en: I met him for the first time since he graduated from school.

examples.kr: 요즘 우리 동네에 이사 온 이래로 친구가 한 명도 없어져서 정말로 외로워요.
examples.romaji: Yojum uri dongne-e isa on iraero chinguga han myeongdo eopseojyeoseo jeongmalro oeroweoyo.
examples.en: I've been really lonely since I moved to our neighborhood these days, as I have no friends at all.

examples.kr: 퇴근한 이래 바쁘게 일을 처리하느라 휴식도 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Towig-han irae bappeuge ileul cheolihaneula hyusikdo mot haess-eoyo.
examples.en: I haven't been able to rest since I finished work because I've been busy handling affairs.

title: ~이므로 [imyeo] (Because, so)
short_explanation: Used to express a reason or cause; 'because', 'so'.
long_explanation: The Korean grammar point '이므로 [imyeo]' is a conjunctive adverb that is used to present a cause or reason and it typically comes in the middle of a sentence. It can be translated into English as 'because' or 'so'. It indicates that the preceding clause is the reason or cause for the information in clause that follows.
formation: Noun + 이다 + 이므로 / Adj. Verb + 이므로

examples.kr: 오늘 비가 오므로 나는 우산을 가져갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Oneul biga omuro naneun usaneul gajyeogassseubnida.
examples.en: Because it is raining today, I brought an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그녀는 좋은 성적을 받으므로 기가 막히다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun joheun seongjeogeul badeumuro giga makida.
examples.en: Because she's received good grades, it's astonishing.

examples.kr: 이 작업은 어렵므로 조심해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: I jageobeun eoryeoumuro josimhaeya haseupnida.
examples.en: Because this job is difficult, you need to be careful.

examples.kr: 내일로 치료를 미루지 마세요, 왜냐하면 상황이 심각하므로.
examples.romaji: Naeillo chiryoreul miruji maseyo, waenyahamyeon sanghwangi simgagimuro.
examples.en: Do not postpone the treatment until tomorrow, because the situation is serious.

title: ~이어서 [ieoseo] (And then, so)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a following action or outcome as a result of a preceding event; 'and then', 'so'.
long_explanation: '~이어서 [ieoseo]' is a conjunction used in Korean to narrate events in chronological order, or explain outcomes as a result of preceding situations. It translates to 'and then' when used to connect successive events and 'so' when used to denote an outcome or a result of a cause. It is useful in storytelling and sharing experiences or explaining logical sequences.
formation: Action Verb + -아/어서, depending on vowel harmony

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 일찍 집에 와서 책을 읽었어요. 책을 읽은 후에는 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul iljjik jibe waseo chaegul ilgosseoyo. Chaegul ilkun hueneun jasseoyo.
examples.en: I came home early today and then read a book. After reading the book, I slept.

examples.kr: 오늘 아침에 비가 와서 나가기 힘들었어요, 그래서 집에서 쉬었어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul achime biga waseo nagagi himdeureosseoyo, geuraeseo jibeseo swieosseoyo.
examples.en: It was raining this morning so it was hard to go outside, so I rested at home.

examples.kr: 친구를 만나러 가게 되었어요. 맛있는 음식을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannareo gage doeeosseoyo. Mashit-neun eumsigeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I ended up meeting a friend. And then, we ate delicious food.

examples.kr: 고양이를 보았어요, 너무 귀여워서 사진을 찍었어요.
examples.romaji: Goyangireul boatseoyo, neomu gwiyeowoseo sajineul jjigeosseoyo.
examples.en: I saw a cat and it was so cute, so I took a photo.

title: ~이지만 [ijiman] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express 'but' or 'however' in a sentence, showing contrast or contradiction.
long_explanation: '~이지만 [ijiman]' is a conjunctive expression used in Korean to show contrast or contradiction between two clauses. It can be translated to 'but' or 'however' in English. Typically, the clause before ~이지만 states something positive or desirable, and the clause after ~이지만 introduces a conflicting point or negates the prior clause, creating a sense of contrast or contradiction.

examples.kr: 날씨가 매우 좋이지만, 제가 외출할 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga maeu joijiman, jega oechulhal sigani eopseoyo.
examples.en: The weather is very nice, but I have no time to go out.

examples.kr: 저는 피자를 좋아하이지만, 다이어트 때문에 먹을 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun pijareul joahaijiman, daieoteu ttaemune meogeul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I like pizza, but I can't eat it because of my diet.

examples.kr: 이 노래는 유명 이지만, 저는 별로 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I noraeneun yumyeong ijiman, jeoneun byeollo joahaji anhayo.
examples.en: This song is famous, but I don't really like it.

examples.kr: 친구가 저에게 돈을 줄 것이라고 약속했지만, 아직도 받지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga jeoege doneul jul geotirago yaksokhaetjiman, ajikdo badji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: My friend promised to give me some money, but I still haven't received it.

title: ~인/는데 [in/neunde] (But, so)
short_explanation: Used to express a contrast, reason, or cause; 'but', 'so'.
long_explanation: '~인/는데 [in/neunde]' is a conjunction used in Korean to connect two sentences, indicating a contrast or a reason between the two sentences. It could translate into 'but', 'so', 'however', or 'although' in English. It is used to connect the clauses, express reason or cause, being the starting of the next expression, or connect contrasting situations or conditions.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋은데 외출하지 않을 거 같아요, 저는 집에서 영화를 보려고 해요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga johneunde oechulhaji anheul geo gatayo, jeoneun jibeseo yeonghwareul boryeogo haeyo.
examples.en: The weather is good today, but I think I won't go out. I plan to watch a movie at home.

examples.kr: 잠을 잘 수 있었는데 알람 소리 때문에 일어났어요.
examples.romaji: Jameul jal su isseossneunde allam sori ttaemune ileonasseoyo.
examples.en: I could have slept well, but I woke up because of the alarm sound.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우고 있는데 발음이 어려워서 가끔 힘들어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangug-eoleul baeugo issneunde bal-um-i eolyeowoseo gakkeum himdeul-eoyo.
examples.en: I am learning Korean, but sometimes it's hard because the pronunciation is difficult.

examples.kr: 구직 심사가 어려웠는데, 다행히도 í요 직업을 찾을 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Gu-jig sim-sa-ga eo-ryeowossneunde, da-haeng-hi-do i yo jik-eob-eul chaj-eul su iss-eoss-eoyo.
examples.en: The job hunting process was tough, but fortunately, I was able to find this job.

title: ~자 [ja] (Let’s)
short_explanation: Used to suggest or propose an action; 'let's'.
long_explanation: '~자 [ja]' is a conjugation used in Korean to suggest, propose, or encourage an action, similar to the English phrase 'let's'. It is often used in an informal context, and is usually appended directly to the verb stem. In conversations, it's a useful phrase to propose an idea on what to do.

examples.kr: 우리 영화보러 가자, 여기에 있는 신작 영화를 봐야 해요.
examples.romaji: Uri yeonghwaboreo gaja, yeogie issneun sinjak yeonghwareul bwaya haeyo.
examples.en: Let's go watch a movie, we have to watch the new movie here.

examples.kr: 밖에 날씨가 좋으니까 산책하러 가자.
examples.romaji: Bakke nalssiga johunikka sanchaekhareo gaja.
examples.en: The weather is nice outside, let's go for a walk.

examples.kr: 지금부터 공부하자, 시험은 가까운데 아직 개념을 이해하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeumbuteo gongbuhaja, siheomeun gakkaunde ajik gaenyeomeul ihaehaji mothayeo.
examples.en: Let's study from now on, the exam is near and I still don't understand the concept.

examples.kr: 맛있는 점심을 먹었으니까 잠깐 쉬자, 배가 너무 부르니까 좀 쉬어요.
examples.romaji: Masissneun jeomsimeul meogeossunikka jamkkan swija, baega neomu bureunikka jom swieoyo.
examples.en: We had a delicious lunch, so let's take a break, my stomach is so full that I need to rest.

title: ~자마자 [jamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that event B occurs immediately after event A.
long_explanation: '~자마자 [jamaja]' is a conjugation used in Korean to indicate that an event B occurs immediately or directly after event A. It is akin to 'as soon as' in English. It is commonly used when you want to emphasize that there was no gap or delay between two actions. The action expressed in the first clause comes directly without any pause after the action in the second clause.

examples.kr: 학교에 도착하자마자 친구를 만났어요. 아침에 너무 바빠서 전화도 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoe dochakhamjamaja chingureul mannasseoyo. Achime neomu bappaseo jeonhwado mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I arrived at school, I met my friend. I was so busy in the morning that I couldn't even call.

examples.kr: 문을 열자마자 고양이가 나가버렸어요. 한시도 쉬지 않고 찾아야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Muneul yeoljamaja goyangiga nagabeoryeosseoyo. Hansido swiji anhgo chajaya haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I opened the door, the cat ran out. I had to search without resting for a moment.

examples.kr: 비행기가 착륙하자마자 핸드폰을 켰어요. 중요한 전화가 있을 줄 알았어요.
examples.romaji: Bihaenggiga chakryukhamjamaja haendeuponeul kyeosseoyo. Jungyohan jeonhwaga isseul jul alasseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as the airplane landed, I turned on my cell phone. I thought there would be an important call.

examples.kr: 집에 돌아오자마자 씻었어요. 오늘 너무 더워서 꼭 씻어야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jibe doraojamaja ssisseosseoyo. Oneul neomu deowoseo ggok ssisseoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as I got home, I took a shower. It was so hot today that I had to shower.

title: ~처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as)
short_explanation: Used to express similarity or imitation; 'like', 'as'.
long_explanation: '~처럼 [cheoreom]' is a postposition used in Korean to show comparison, resemblance, or imitation. It is often translated as 'like' or 'as' in English and compares two different things, expressing that one thing is similar to or acts like another. You can use it with both nouns and verbs.

examples.kr: 그의 눈은 별처럼 반짝반짝 빛나고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui nuneun byeolcheoreom banjjakbanjjak bitnago isseoyo.
examples.en: His eyes are shining like stars.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 늘 날개가 달린 말처럼 열심히 일해요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun neul nalgae ga dallin malcheoreom yeolsimhi ilhaeyo.
examples.en: My father always works hard as if he was a horse with wings.

examples.kr: 그녀는 수영을 물고기처럼 잘 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun suyeongeul mulgogicheoreom jal haeyo.
examples.en: She swims as well as a fish.

examples.kr: 오늘 하루 종일 나는 새처럼 자유롭게 날아다녔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul haru jongil naneun saecheoreom jayurobge naradanwosseoyo.
examples.en: I flew around freely like a bird all day today.

title: ~쯤 [jjeum] (Around, about)
short_explanation: Used to indicate approximation; 'around', 'about'.
long_explanation: '쯤 [jjeum]' is a suffixed particle used in Korean to demonstrate approximation or estimated range. It is often used when the speaker is not sure of the exact amount, time, or degree but gives an approximate idea. It can be compared to the English equivalent of 'around' or 'about' and is used in a variety of contexts to loosely define a quantity, time, or degree without stating an exact value.
formation: Noun (relating to number, quantity, or time) + 쯤

examples.kr: 시험이 어렵기 때문에 공부를 하루에 3시간쯤은 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Siheom-i eoryeobgikkaji, gongbu-chingchaneuro 3si-gan-jjeum-eun haeya ha-yo.
examples.en: Because the exam is difficult, you have to study about 3 hours a day.

examples.kr: 저희 집에서 버스로 가면 약 20분쯤 걸릴 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeohui jipeseo beoseuro gamyeon yak 20bunjjeum geollil geot gatayo.
examples.en: It seems like it will take about 20 minutes to get there by bus from my house.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 더워서 온도가 30도쯤 될 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga deowoseo ondogu 30dojjeum doel geot gatayo.
examples.en: Since the weather is hot today, I think the temperature will be around 30 degrees.

examples.kr: 그 책을 읽으려면 한주 정도쯤 걸릴 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geu chaekeul ilgeuryeomyeon hanju jeongdojjeum geollil geot gatayo.
examples.en: I think it will take about a week to read that book.

title: ~지 않다 [ji anta] (Not)
short_explanation: Used to express a negative verb or sentence; 'Not'.
long_explanation: '~지 않다 [ji anta]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express negative verbs or sentences. It literally means 'not', turning a verb into a negative. It is attached directly to the verb stem, removing the '다' from the dictionary form of the verb. This formation is used in both formal and informal settings, and helps express a negation or refusal of action.

examples.kr: 제가 이번 회의에 참석하지 않을 것입니다, 왜냐하면 그 시간에 다른 중요한 일정이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jega ibeon hoeuie chamseokji anteu geosimnida, waenyahamyeon geu sigane dareun jungyohan iljeongi isseoyo.
examples.en: I will not attend this meeting because I have another important schedule at that time.

examples.kr: 우리 아빠는 흡연하지 않아요, 그래서 우리 집은 항상 신선한 공기가 가득해요.
examples.romaji: Uri appaneun heubyunji anhnayo, geuraeseo uri jip-eun hangsang sinseonhan gong-gi-ga gadeughaeyo.
examples.en: My father does not smoke, so our house is always full of fresh air.

examples.kr: 그녀는 항상 밝은 표정을 지니지 않아서 다른 사람들로부터 거리감을 느껴요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangsang balgeun pyojeongeul jiniji anhaseo dareun saramdeulrobuteo georigameul neukyeoyo.
examples.en: She does not always have a bright expression, so she feels distanced from other people.

examples.kr: 저는 육류를 먹지 않아요, 그래서 항상 채식주의에 맞는 식사를 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yuklyureul meokji anhayo, geuraeseo hangsang chaesikjuuie majneun sigsareul haeya haeyo.
examples.en: I do not eat meat, so I always have to eat a vegetarian diet.

title: ~지만 [jiman] (But)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~지만 [jiman]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate a contrasting situation or contradiction. It conveys a sense of 'but' or 'however' in English. It is utilized when the speaker wants to present a fact or situation that seems to contradict or contrast with another fact or situation that has been talked about prior.

examples.kr: 저는 아주 피곤하지만, 이일을 끝내야 해서 계속해야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun aju pigonhajiman, iireul kkeunnaeya haeseo gyesokhaeya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: I'm very tired, but I think I have to keep going because I have to finish this work.

examples.kr: 그 음식은 맛이 없지만, 영양이 가득해서 먹어야해요.
examples.romaji: Geu eumsikeun masi eobjiman, yeongangi gadeukhaeseo meogeoya haeyo.
examples.en: The food is not tasty, but I have to eat it because it's full of nutrients.

examples.kr: 여러분들 중에는 문제가 어렵다고 느낀 사람도 있겠지만, 포기하면 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Yeoreobundeul jungeoneun munjega eoryeobdagoneun nigan saramdo itgetjiman, pogihamyeon an doeyo.
examples.en: There might be some of you who find the problem difficult, but you should not give up.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 좋지만, 명확히 의견을 말하는 것은 좀 어려워해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seonggyeogi joajiman, myeonghwakhi uigyeongeul malhaneun geoseun jom eoryeowo haeyo.
examples.en: He has a good personality, but he finds it a bit difficult to express his opinions clearly.

title: ~지요/~죠 [jiyo/jyo] (Isn’t it?, right?)
short_explanation: Used to confirm or seek agreement on a statement; 'isn't it?', 'right?'
long_explanation: The '지요' or '죠' ending is a way to seek an agreement or confirmation from the listener, kind of like saying ‘right?’ or ‘isn’t it?’ at the end of sentences in English. It can be used in both informal and formal contexts, differing mainly in politeness level. It is a softer way of asserting something, and can also be used to request a confirmation from the person you are speaking to.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋아지요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joajyo.
examples.en: The weather is nice today, isn't it?

examples.kr: 우리는 같은 반에 있었지요?
examples.romaji: Urineun gateun bane isseotjiyo?
examples.en: We were in the same class, right?

examples.kr: 이 일을 끝내야겠죠?
examples.romaji: I ireul kkeutnaeyagetjyo?
examples.en: We have to finish this work, don't we?

examples.kr: 그 영화 진짜 재미있었지요?
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwa jinjja jaemiisseotjiyo?
examples.en: That movie was really fun, wasn't it?

title: ~하고 [hago] (And, with)
short_explanation: '~하고 [hago]' is used to connect nouns and verb stems to indicate 'and', 'with', or 'as'.
long_explanation: '~하고 [hago]' is a postposition in Korean that indicates conjunction or inclusion. When used between two nouns, it corresponds to 'and' in English and indicates that both nouns are involved in the situation. When used between a noun and a verb, '~하고 [hago]' corresponds to 'with' in English and indicates a role of a noun in the action
formation: Noun1 + 하고 + Noun2 (to indicate and) / Noun + 하고 + Verb (to indicate with)

examples.kr: 저는 커피하고 도넛을 주문했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopi hago doneuteul jumunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I ordered coffee and doughnuts.

examples.kr: 우리는 함께하고 이야기하며 즐거운 시간을 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun hamkke hago iyagihameyhe jeulgeoun siganeul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: We had a good time talking and being together.

examples.kr: 나는 딸기하고 바나나를 믹서에 넣어 스무디를 만들었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ttalgihago bananareul mikseo-e neoh-eo seumudireul mandeuleosseoyo.
examples.en: I put strawberries and bananas in a blender and made a smoothie.

examples.kr: 그는 친구하고 축구를 하려고 공원에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: geuneun chinguhago chukgureul haryeogo gong-won-e gass-eoyo.
examples.en: He went to the park to play soccer with his friend.

title: ~하기로 [hagiro] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Used to express a decision made to do something.
long_explanation: '~하기로 [hagiro]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate that a decision has been made to do a certain action. It is widely used in daily conversations to tell about decisions, plans or arrange meetings. It can be translated as ‘decide to’ in English and is often used to express a decision or resolve.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 서울로 가기로 결정했어요, 그곳에서 친구들을 만나기로 해서요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil Seoul-lo gagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo, geugoseseo chingudeul-eul mannagiro haesyeoyo.
examples.en: We decided to go to Seoul tomorrow, because we decided to meet friends there.

examples.kr: 나는 다음 달에 새로운 일을 시작하기로 결정했습니다, 이번 일은 너무 지루해서요.
examples.romaji: Naneun daeum dal-e saelong-ui ileul sijakagiro gyeoljeonghaessseubnida, ibeon il-eun neumu jiruhagyieyo.
examples.en: I decided to start a new job next month, because this job is too boring.

examples.kr: 우리 가족은 다음 주말에 피크닉 가기로 했어요, 날씨가 좋을 예정이라서요.
examples.romaji: Uli gajok-eun da-eum ju-mal-e picnic gagiro haesseoyo, nalssi-ga joh-eul yejeong-irasheoyo.
examples.en: Our family decided to go for a picnic next weekend, because the weather is expected to be good.

examples.kr: 나는 하루에 한 시간 독서하기로 결정했어요, 독서는 지식을 증가시켜주기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Naneun haru-e hansigan dogseohagiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo, dogseo-neun jisig-eul jeungga sikyeojugi tta-mun-ieyo.
examples.en: I decided to read for one hour every day, because reading increases knowledge.

title: ~하기는 [hagineun] (But)
short_explanation: Used to introduce a contrasting clause or point; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~하기는 [hagineun]' is a complex form used in Korean grammar to introduce a contrasting viewpoint or situation. It is translated as 'but', 'however', or 'on the other hand' in English. This form is often used when the speaker wants to express a different perspective or highlight a contrast between two ideas, events or conditions.

examples.kr: 그 날씨가 추웠기는 했지만, 우리는 아직도 즐거운 시간을 보냈어요.
examples.romaji: Geu nalssiga chuweossgineun haetjiman, urineun ajikdo jeulgeoun siganeul bonaesseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was cold, but we still had a good time.

examples.kr: 이 새별을 좋아하기는 해도, 이것은 너무 비싸서 사기 어려워요.
examples.romaji: I saebyeoreul johahagineun haedo, igeoseun neomu bissaseo sagi eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: I do like this new star, but it's too expensive to buy.

examples.kr: 요리를 잘하긴 하나, 요리를 하기위해 들이는 시간과 노력이 많이 필요해요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul jalhagineun hana, yorireul hagiwihae deurineun sigangwa noryeogi mani piryohaeyo.
examples.en: I am good at cooking, but it requires a lot of time and effort to cook.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 좋기는 한데, 종종 늦게 오는 습관이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seonggyeogi jogeum joahagineun hande, jongjong neujge oneun seubgwani iss-eoyo.
examples.en: He has a good personality, but he often has a habit of coming late.

title: ~하기보다 [hagiboda] (Rather than)
short_explanation: Used to express 'rather than', 'instead of' or 'in preference to'.
long_explanation: '~하기보다 [hagiboda]' is a conjunctive form used in Korean to contrast or compare two actions, states, or situations. It's used to express a preference for one thing over another, essentially meaning 'rather than' or 'instead of' in English. The first verb before 'hagiboda' indicates the less preferred action, and the coming verb after 'hagiboda' indicates the more preferred action.

examples.kr: 저는 차를 운전하기보다 버스를 타는 것이 더 편하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chareul unjeonhagiboda beoseureul taneun geosi deo pyeonhadago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I think it's more comfortable to take a bus rather than driving a car.

examples.kr: 음식을 사 먹기보다 직접 요리하는 것이 더 건강해요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigeul sa meokgiboda jikjeop yorihaneun geosi deo geonganghaeyo.
examples.en: Cooking for yourself is healthier than buying food.

examples.kr: 집에서 일하기보다 사무실에서 작업하는 것이 더 생산적이라고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Jibeseo ilhagiboda samusilesseo jageobhaneun geosi deo saengsanjeogirago saenggakhamnida.
examples.en: I think working in the office is more productive than working at home.

examples.kr: 돈을 벌기보다 친구들과 함께 시간을 보내는 게 더 중요하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Doneul beolgiboda chingudeulgwa hamkke siganeul bonaeneun ge deo jungyohadago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I think spending time with friends is more important than making money.

title: ~하나 [hana] (Questioning oneself)
short_explanation: This particle is used to question oneself or ponder over something.
long_explanation: The '~하나 [hana]' ending is used in Korean to express self-questioning or puzzling over something. It is frequently used in informal, conversational language when the speaker is wondering or considering something, asking themselves a question, or trying to understand something perplexing. The English equivalent might be something like 'I wonder' or 'Could it be'.

examples.kr: 나는 왜 항상 혼자인지 모르겠는 하나.
examples.romaji: Naneun wae hangsang honjainji moreugneun hana.
examples.en: I wonder why I'm always alone.

examples.kr: 왜 그가 저렇게 말했는지 이해가 안 가는 하나.
examples.romaji: Wae geuga jeoreohge malhaessneunji ihaega an ganeun hana.
examples.en: I'm puzzled as to why he said that.

examples.kr: 자주 연락하던 친구가 갑자기 연락이 안 오는 하나.
examples.romaji: Jaju yeonrakhadeon chinguga gapjagi yeonraki an oneun hana.
examples.en: I wonder why the friend who used to contact me often suddenly doesn't contact me.

examples.kr: 공부를 많이 했는데도 시험을 못 본다는 하나.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul mani haessneundedo siheomeul mot bondaneun hana.
examples.en: I wonder why, despite studying a lot, I can't take the test.

title: ~하다가 [hadaga] (Doing and then)
short_explanation: Used to express the notion of 'doing something and then'.
long_explanation: '~하다가 [hadaga]' is a composite verb form in Korean which is used to express the notion of 'doing something and then'. It signifies that while a person was in the middle of doing an action, another event occurred. The first action does not necessarily have to be completed for the second action to happen. Often, the second action interrupts the first one.

examples.kr: 청소를 하다가 우연히 오래된 사진을 발견했어요.
examples.romaji: Cheongso reul hadaga uyeonhi oraedoen sajineul balgyeonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: While I was cleaning, I happened to find an old photo.

examples.kr: 저는 책을 읽다가 잠이 들었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chaekeul ilkda ga jami deureosseoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book, and then I fell asleep.

examples.kr: 친구와 이야기를 하다가 시간을 잊었어요.
examples.romaji: Chingu wa iyagireul hadaga siganeul ilheosseoyo.
examples.en: I was talking with my friend and lost track of time.

examples.kr: 운전을 하다가 길을 잃었습니다.
examples.romaji: Unjeoneul hadaga gireul ilheosseumnida.
examples.en: I was driving and got lost.

title: ~하다가 말다 [hadaga malda] (Stop doing something)
short_explanation: Used to express someone or something that stops in the course of doing something.
long_explanation: '~하다가 말다 [hadaga malda]' is a grammar point in Korean language that depicts an action or behavior that got interrupted or stopped while it was being executed. It often implies that the action was stopped before it was fully completed, with the potential to resume at a later time. It's often used to highlight sudden change, interruption or unforeseen situations that cause the action to cease. The verb precedes '하다가 말다' is in dictionary form
formation: Verb in dictionary form + 하다가 말다

examples.kr: 공부하다가 말았어요, 왜냐하면 알람이 안 울려서 시간을 잊어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhadaga malasseoyo, waenyahamyeon allam-i an ullyeoseo sigan-eul ij-eobeolyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I was studying and then I stopped, because I forgot the time as the alarm did not ring.

examples.kr: 친구가 집에 왔기 때문에 저는 밥 요리하다가 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga jib-e wasseugi ttaemun-e jeoneun bab yoli hadaga mal-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: I was cooking rice but then I stopped because my friend came over.

examples.kr: 운동하다가 말았어요, 왜냐하면 비가 너무 많이 왔기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Undonghadaga malasseoyo, waenyahamyeon biga neomu mani wasgi ttaemun-ibnida.
examples.en: I was exercising and then I stopped, because it was raining too much.

examples.kr: 책을 읽다가 말았어요, 왜냐하면 갑자기 잠이 와서입니다.
examples.romaji: Chaeg-eul ilgdaga mal-ass-eoyo, waenyahamyeon gabjagi jam-i waseoibnida.
examples.en: I was reading a book and then I stopped, because I suddenly felt sleepy.

title: ~하더라 [hadeora] (I observed, I remember)
short_explanation: Used to express recollection or observation of a past event.
long_explanation: '~하더라 [hadeora]' is a Korean grammar pattern that denotes someone's personal experience, observation, or feeling of a certain event in the past. It indicates something that was perceived or noticed, oftentimes used when sharing personal memories or observations with someone else. Unlike ~했다, which simply states a past fact, ~하더라 provides a hint that the speaker personally witnessed or experienced something.

examples.kr: 너의 여동생은 참 예쁘더라, 동네에서 가장 예쁜 소녀로 알려져 있었어.
examples.romaji: Neoui yeodongsaengeun cham yeppeudeora, dongneeseo gajang yeppeun sonyeoro allyeojyeo isseosseo.
examples.en: Your younger sister is very pretty, she was known as the most beautiful girl in the neighborhood.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 바빠 보였더라, 따라서 그와 만날 시간을 찾기 어려웠어.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang bappa boyeossdeora, ttaraseo geuwa mannal siganeul chatgi eoryeosseo.
examples.en: He always seemed busy, so I found it difficult to find a time to meet with him.

examples.kr: 우리 아빠는 어릴 때 축구를 잘했더라, 그래서 아직도 그의 축구 실력이 대단해.
examples.romaji: Uri appaneun eoril ttae chukgureul jalhaessdeora, geuraeseo ajikdo geui chukgu sillagi daedanhae.
examples.en: My father was good at soccer when he was young, so his soccer skills are still great.

examples.kr: 작년에 우리가 해변에 갔던 때, 해가 질 때가 참 예뻤더라.
examples.romaji: Jagnyeon-e uri-ga haebyeon-e gassdeon ttae, hae-ga jil ttae-ga cham yeppeossdeora.
examples.en: Last year when we went to the beach, the sunset was really beautiful.

title: ~하려고 [haryeogo] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express purpose or intention; 'in order to', 'for the purpose of'.
long_explanation: '~하려고 [haryeogo]' is a Korean grammar pattern used to indicate purpose or intention. In essence, it translates to 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of' in English.
