It is used to explain the reason behind one's actions, or the intended end result. This pattern is commonly seen at the end of a sentence, and is often used with verbs to indicate the intention behind the action.

examples.kr: 한국어를 더 잘 이해하려고 많은 책을 읽었습니다.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoreul deo jal ihaeharyeogo manheun chaegeul ilgeotsseumnida.
examples.en: I read many books in order to understand Korean better.

examples.kr: 시험을 잘 보기 위해 열심히 공부하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul jal bogi wihae yeolsimhi gongbuharyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: I am studying hard in order to do well on the test.

examples.kr: 건강을 유지하려고 운동하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geongangeul yujiharyeogo undonghago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am exercising in order to maintain my health.

examples.kr: 여행 때문에 돈을 모으려고 아르바이트를 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng ttaemune doneul moeuryeogo areubaiteureul haesseoyo.
examples.en: I did a part-time job in order to save money for the trip.

title: ~하여/해서 [hayeo/haeseo] (So, therefore)
short_explanation: Connective ending used to express reason or cause.
long_explanation: '~하여/해서 [hayeo/haeseo]' is a connective verb ending used in Korean to link two clauses where the first clause is the cause or reason for the second clause. The second clause, the result or effect, presents a factual or logical outcome from the first clause. It correlates with 'So' or 'Therefore' in English. The shorter form '해서' is more colloquial and often used in daily conversation.

examples.kr: 비가 오는데서 집에 늦게 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneun daeseo jibe neutge wasseoyo.
examples.en: Because it was raining, I came home late.

examples.kr: 컴퓨터가 망가져서 과제를 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Keompyuteoga manggajyeo-seo gwajereul mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: Because the computer broke, I couldn't do the assignment.

examples.kr: 열심히 공부해서 시험에 잘 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Yeolsimhi gongbuhaeseo siheome jal bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I studied hard, so I did well on the test.

examples.kr: 빵을 너무 많이 먹어서 배가 아팠어요.
examples.romaji: Bbangeul neomu mani meogeoseo baega apasseoyo.
examples.en: I ate too much bread, so my stomach hurt.

title: ~한테/한테서 [hante/hanteseo] (To/From someone)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'to' or 'from' someone in Korean.
long_explanation: '~한테/한테서 [hante/hanteseo]' is used to show the direction or target of the action in Korean, indicating 'to' or 'from' respectively. It is most commonly used with animate objects, usually people. It can refer to both physical and metaphorical direction. When used with a verb, '한테' shows who is receiving the action while '한테서' shows who is the source of the action.

examples.kr: 제가 친구한테 선물을 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Jega chinguhante seonmureul jueosseoyo.
examples.en: I gave a gift to my friend.

examples.kr: 제가 선생님한테서 한국어를 배웠어요.
examples.romaji: Jega seonsaengnimhanteso hangugeoreul baewosseoyo.
examples.en: I learned Korean from my teacher.

examples.kr: 그의 아버지한테서 돈을 빌렸어요.
examples.romaji: Geuui abeojihanteso doneul billyeosseoyo.
examples.en: He borrowed money from his father.

examples.kr: 나한테 좋은 말만 해주세요.
examples.romaji: Nahante joheun manman haejuseyo.
examples.en: Please, only say nice things to me.

title: ~할 거예요 [hal geoyeyo] (Going to do)
short_explanation: Used to express future plans or intentions; 'going to do'.
long_explanation: '~할 거예요 [hal geoyeyo]' is a future tense verb ending used in Korean to indicate a plan or intention in the future. It is most closely translated to 'going to do' in English. It is often used in sentences to express an intention or plan to do something in the future.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 친구들과 함께 캠핑을 갈 거예요, 텐트와 캠핑 용품을 준비해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumare chingudeulgwa hamkke kaempingeul gal geoyeyo, tenteuwa kaemping yongpumeul junbihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I am going to go camping with my friends this weekend, I have to prepare tents and camping supplies.

examples.kr: 내일은 날씨가 좋으니까 공원에서 산책할 거예요, 맑은 날씨를 즐길 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun nalssiga joheunikka gongwoneso sancaekhal geoyeyo, malgeun nalssireul jeulgil su isseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I'm going to go for a walk in the park tomorrow, because the weather will be nice, I will be able to enjoy the clear weather.

examples.kr: 저는 저녁에 스파게티를 요리할 거예요, 스파게티 소스와 파스타를 구입해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jeonyeoge seupagetireul yorihal geoyeyo, seupageti soseuwa pasauteureul guibhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I am going to cook spaghetti in the evening, I have to buy spaghetti sauce and pasta.

examples.kr: 아버지가 퇴근하면 함께 식당에서 저녁을 먹을 거예요, 아버지가 좋아하는 음식을 선택해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Abeojiga toegeunhamyeon hamkke sikdangeseo jeonyeogeul meogeul geoyeyo, abeojiga joahaneun eumsigeul seontaekhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: When my father comes home from work, we're going to eat dinner at a restaurant, I have to choose the food my father likes.

title: ~할 만하다 [hal manhada] (Worth doing)
short_explanation: This expression is used to state that something is worth the effort or time; 'worth doing'.
long_explanation: '~할 만하다 [hal manhada]' is a commonly used grammar point in Korean which means that something is worth doing. It can be used with a verb stem to indicate that the action or behavior of the verb is worth the effort, cost or time that would be needed to do it. This grammar point often suggests that even though the action might require some effort, the value or benefit gained from performing it outweighs the cost or effort.

examples.kr: 이 여행은 비싸지만 가볼 만해요, 왜냐하면 그 곳은 정말 아름답기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: I yeohaengeun bissajiman gabol manhaeyo, waenahamyeon geu gos-eun jeongmal aleumdabgi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: This trip is expensive, but it's worth going to because the place is really beautiful.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 길지만 보는 만합니다, 왜냐하면 스토리가 정말 재미있기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun giljiman boneun manhamnida, waenahamyeon seutoriga jeongmal jaemiissgi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: This movie is long, but it's worth watching because the story is really interesting.

examples.kr: 이 책은 두껍지만 읽을 만해요, 왜냐하면 그 콘텐츠는 정말 유익하기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: I chaegeun duggobjiman ilgeul manhaeyo, waenahamyeon geu kontencheuneun jeongmal yuighagi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: This book is thick, but it's worth reading because its content is really beneficial.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 멀지만 가볼 만해요, 왜냐하면 그 음식은 진짜 맛있기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: I sikdangeun meoljiman gabol manhaeyo, waenahamyeon geu eumsikeun jinjja mashitgi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: This restaurant is far, but it's worth going to because the food is really delicious.

title: ~할 수록 [hal surok] (The more...)
short_explanation: Used to describe a situation where one action or state increases or intensifies as another action or state does.
long_explanation: '~할 수록 [hal surok]' is a compound grammar pattern used to express a situation where as one thing happens, another thing happens correspondingly. Essentially, it means 'the more...'. It is used to convey a sense of proportionality or dependency relating two different elements, often employed when the progress of one situation affects the state of another. It may be used in various contexts and situations. Note that both clauses in the sentence usually share the same subject.
formation: Verb stem + 할 수록 + Increasing situation

examples.kr: 그녀를 알게 될수록 나는 그녀를 더 사랑하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoreul alge doelsurok naneun geunyeoreul deo saranghage dweeosseoyo.
examples.en: The more I got to know her, the more I fell in love with her.

examples.kr: 연습을 할수록, 당신의 기술은 더 향상될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Yeonseubeul halsurok, dangsinui gisuleun deo hyangsangdoel geosibnida.
examples.en: The more you practice, the more your skills will improve.

examples.kr: 사람들이 많을수록 파티는 더 즐거워질 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Saramdeuri manheulsurok patineun deo jeulgeowojil geosibnida.
examples.en: The more people there are, the more fun the party will be.

examples.kr: 시간이 흘러갈수록 그의 그립움은 더 커져 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Sigani heulleogalsurok geuui geuripumeun deo keojyeo gasseoyo.
examples.en: As time passed, his longing grew greater.

title: ~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda] (Know how to)
short_explanation: Used to express the knowledge or skill to do something.
long_explanation: '~할 줄 알다 [hal jul alda]' is a Korean grammar point used to indicate the ability or skill to do something. It directly translates as 'know how to do'. It is used when you want to say that someone (including yourself) knows how to do a certain action. This phrase is often used in sentences which expresses the ability, capability, possibility or potentiality.
formation: Verb in Dictionary form + 줄 알다

examples.kr: 나는 요리할 줄 알아요, 그래서 친구들이 집에 놀러 올 때마다 맛있는 음식을 해 줄 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun yorihal jul alyo, geuraeseo chingudeuri jibe nolleo ol ttaemada masitneun eumsigeul hae jul su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I know how to cook, so whenever friends come to play at my house, I can make delicious food.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 한국어를 말할 줄 알아요, 그래서 한국 친구와 자유롭게 대화할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun hangugeoreul malhal jul alyo, geuraeseo hanguk chinguwa jayurobge daehwahal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: My friend knows how to speak Korean, so he can converse freely with Korean friends.

examples.kr: 부모님은 운전을 하실 줄 아셔서, 어디든지 가실 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonim-eun unjeoneul hasil jul ashsyeoseo, eodideunji gasil su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: My parents know how to drive, so they can go anywhere.

examples.kr: 나는 피아노를 칠 줄 알아요, 그래서 친구들과 함께 노래방에 갔을 때 항상 자랑 스럽게 느껴져요.
examples.romaji: Naneun pianoreul chil jul alyo, geuraeseo chingudeulgwa hamkke nolaebang-e gass-eul ttae hangsang jajang seulobge neukkyeojyeoyo.
examples.en: I know how to play the piano, so whenever I go to Karaoke with friends, I always feel proud.

title: ~할지라도 [haljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning 'even if'.
long_explanation: '~할지라도 [haljirado]' is a Korean conjunction that translates to 'even if' in English. It is used when the speaker wants to say that even in the hypothetical condition expressed in the clause that it is attached to, the situation or fact spoken of in the following clause will not change.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지라도 나는 운동하러 갈 거야.
examples.romaji: naeil biga oljirado naneun undonghago galgeoya.
examples.en: Even if it rains tomorrow, I will go to exercise.

examples.kr: 부모님이 그에 대해 싫어할지라도, 나는 그를 계속 만나려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: bumonimi geue daehae sirheohaljirado, naneun geureul gyesog mannaryeogo habnida.
examples.en: Even if my parents dislike him, I intend to keep seeing him.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려울지라도, 열심히 공부했기 때문에 자신이 있어.
examples.romaji: siheomi eoryeouljirado, yeolsimhi gongbuhaetgi ttaemune jasin-i isseo.
examples.en: Even if the exam is hard, I'm confident because I studied hard.

examples.kr: 너가 어떻게 생각할지라도, 나는 그 결정을 후회하지 않아.
examples.romaji: neoga eotteoke saenggakhaljirado, naneun geu gyeoljeongeul hugoehaji anha.
examples.en: Even if you think differently, I do not regret that decision.

title: ~할 텐데 [hal tende] (I thought/would have thought that..)
short_explanation: Used to express a presumption or expectation that has not been realized.
long_explanation: '~할 텐데 [hal tende]' is a grammar construction in Korean used to express a presumption or expectation that has not fulfilled or proven to be inaccurate. It is used when the speaker anticipates a certain outcome but the actual outcome turns out to be different. It can be translated into English as 'I thought/would have thought that..' The assumption here could be based on common sense, general knowledge or particular circumstances, but it does not coincide with the actual result.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋을 텐데 비가 옵니다, 예상이 달랐네요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joheul tende biga omyeon, yesangi dallatneyo.
examples.en: I thought the weather would be good today, but it's raining; my prediction was wrong.

examples.kr: 그는 저녁에 연락할 텐데 아직 연락이 없어요, 어떤 일이 생겼나봐요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jeonyeoke yeonrakhal tende ajik yeonraki eopseoyo, eotteon iri saenggyeonnabwayo.
examples.en: I thought he would contact me in the evening, but he hasn't yet; something must have come up.

examples.kr: 그녀는 항상 분위기가 좋을 텐데 오늘은 왠지 행복해 보이지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangsang bunwigiga joheul tende oneulen waenji haengbokhae boiji anayyo.
examples.en: I thought she's always in a good mood, but for some reason she doesn't look happy today.

examples.kr: 시험은 쉬울 텐데 너무 어렵게 나와서 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeun swiul tende neomu eoryeopge nawayo, nollasseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the exam would be easy, but it turned out to be very difficult, and I was surprised.

title: ~해야지 [haeyaji] (Decide to)
short_explanation: Used to express a personal decision or intention, similar to 'I should' or 'I will' in English.
long_explanation: '~해야지 [haeyaji]' is a useful grammatical structure in Korean which is used to show a decision made by the speaker about doing something in the future. It's typically used when somebody is talking to himself or herself, deciding on what to do next. It can be translated as 'I should' or 'I will' in English. This can also be used when providing a softer suggestion to someone else.

examples.kr: 오늘은 일찍 집에 가야지, 내일 일찍 일어나야 되니까.
examples.romaji: Oneureun iljjik jib-e gayaji, naeil iljjik ileonaya doeni-kka.
examples.en: I should go home early today since I need to wake up early tomorrow.

examples.kr: 건강을 위해 운동을 시작해야지.
examples.romaji: Geongangeul wihae undongeul sijakhaeyaji.
examples.en: I should start exercising for my health.

examples.kr: 나는 다양한 책을 읽어야지, 이렇게 하면 나의 지식을 넓힐 수 있을 것이다.
examples.romaji: Naneun dayang-han chaek-eul ilkeoya-ji, ileohke haemyeon naui jisikeul neolphil su iss-eul geos-ida.
examples.en: I should read a variety of books, by doing so I can broaden my knowledge.

examples.kr: 하지만, 천천히 먹어야지, 그래야 소화가 잘 될 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Hajiman, cheoncheonhi meogeoya-ji, geulaeya sohwaga jal doel geosibnida.
examples.en: But, I should eat slowly, that way, it will digest well.

title: ~해도/해봐도 [haedo/haebwado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Indicates the meaning of 'even if' in sentences.
long_explanation: '~해도/해봐도 [haedo/haebwado]' is a Korean grammar point that conveys the meaning of 'even if' in sentences. It is often used to express an action or situation that does not influence the result or outcome, regardless of whether that action or situation happens or not. It asserts a degree of indifference or certainty about circumstances that might ordinarily be thought of as affecting an outcome.

examples.kr: 여기서 우리가 얼마나 노력을 해봐도, 상황이 개선되지 않습니다.
examples.romaji: Yogi seori ga jan man an haedo, sikeuneegeun gaeb jonhan upnida
examples.en: Even if we try hard here, the situation does not improve.

examples.kr: 그 가게의 음식이 맛있어도, 거기서 일하고 싶지 않아요.
examples.romaji: geu gageyi eumsiki masisseodo, geogiseo ilhago sipji anhayo.
examples.en: Even if the food at that store is delicious, I do not want to work there.

examples.kr: 아무리 많은 돈을 벌어봐도, 행복하지 않다면 의미가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Amuri manheun doneul beoreobwado, haengbokhaji an damyeon uimiga eopseoyo.
examples.en: Even if you earn a lot of money, it’s meaningless if you’re not happy.

examples.kr: 그녀가 얼마나 사랑해봐도, 그녀의 마음을 이해할 수 없어.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga eolmana sarang haebwado, geunyeo e maeumeul ihae hal su ebseo.
examples.en: No matter how much she loves, I cannot understand her feelings.

title: ~해보다 [haeboda] (Try to)
short_explanation: '해보다 [haeboda]' is used to describe an action that someone has tried or attempted to do.
long_explanation: '해보다 [haeboda]' is a verb ending that denotes an attempt or experience of trying something. It is used when one attempts to do something for the first time or when suggesting or advising someone to try something. It is a combination of an action verb and '보다' that adds the meaning of 'try' to the basic verb.

examples.kr: 나는 새로운 한국 음식을 먹어보려고 노력했지만, 그것은 너무 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun saeroun hanguk eumsigeul meogeoboryeogo noryeokhaetjiman, geugeoseun neomu eoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to eat new Korean food, but it was too difficult.

examples.kr: 당신은 이 새로운 언어를 배워보는 것에 대해 어떻게 생각하세요?
examples.romaji: Dangsineun i saeroun eoneoreul baeweoboneun geose daehae eotteoke saengakhayo?
examples.en: What do you think about trying to learn this new language?

examples.kr: 처음에는 읽기가 어려웠지만, 계속 해보니까 서서히 알게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum-eneun ilgigiga eoryeosseotjiman, gyesok haebonikka seoseohi alge dweeosseoyo.
examples.en: Reading was difficult at first, but as I kept trying, I gradually understood.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 새로운 취미를 찾아보는 것은 어떨까요?
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumale saeroun chwimireul chajaboneun geoseun eotteolkka yo?
examples.en: How about trying to find a new hobby this weekend?

title: ~해주다 [haejuda] (Do for someone)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express the intention of doing something for someone else.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~해주다 [haejuda]' is used to indicate that the speaker will do something for another person, or to express a kind action one person does for another. It is frequently used in situations where a person is helping another by doing something beneficial for them. The literal English equivalent for '~해주다' could be considered something along the lines of 'to do something for someone', but in a more altruistic or considerate sense.

examples.kr: 저는 어머니께 밥을 해주려고 요리를 배우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eomeonikke babeul haejuryeogo yorireul baeugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I’m learning to cook to make meals for my mother.

examples.kr: 친구가 시험 공부가 힘들어서 저는 친구를 위해서 정리를 해주었어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga siheom gongbuga himdeureoseo jeoneun chingureul wihaeseo jeongrireul haejueosseoyo.
examples.en: My friend was struggling with exam revision, so I summarized it for her.

examples.kr: 아버지가 피곤하셔서 제가 운전을 해주었습니다.
examples.romaji: Abeojiga pigonhasyeoseo jega unjeoneul haejueossseubnida.
examples.en: My father was tired, so I drove for him.

examples.kr: 우리 팀원들이 바빠서 나는 이번 보고서를 대신 작성해주었어요.
examples.romaji: Uli timwondeuli bappaseo naneun ibeon bogoseoreul daesin jakseonghaejueosseoyo.
examples.en: Our team members were busy, so I wrote this report for them.

title: ~했더니 [haetdeoni] (When, and then)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express 'when something happened and then something else happened as a result'.
long_explanation: '~했더니 [haetdeoni]' is a grammar point used in Korean to signify a cause-and-effect relationship where the first action directly leads to the second action. This construction denotes 'when I did [first action] and then [second action] happened'. It is often used in instances when the result is unexpected or surprising, emphasizing that the second action is a direct result of the first action.
formation: Verb in past tense + 더니 + Resulting action or state

examples.kr: 저는 이 케이크를 먹었더니, 막상 맛있어서 더 먹고 싶었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i keikeureul meogeosseodeoni, maksang masisseoseo deo meokgo sippeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I ate this cake, it was surprisingly delicious and I wanted to eat more.

examples.kr: 나는 출근했더니 사무실에 누가 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chulgeunhaessdeoni samusile nuga eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I came to work, there was nobody in the office.

examples.kr: 나는 이 책을 읽었더니 처음 생각했던 것보다 훨씬 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun i chaegeul ilgeossdeoni cheoeum saenggakhaessdeon geotboda hwolssin jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I read this book, it was much more interesting than I initially thought.

examples.kr: 나는 친구를 만났더니 오랜만에 보니까 정말 기쁘었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingureul mannassdeoni oraenmane bonigga jeongmal gippueosseoyo.
examples.en: When I met my friend, I was really happy because it's been a long time since we last saw each other.

title: ~했었다 [haesseotda] (Had done)
short_explanation: Used to describe an action that had been done in the past, before another action or situation.
long_explanation: '~했었다' [haesseotda]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express an action that had been completed before another event or action occurred. This form is similar to the English past perfect tense, often used to explain a past event or situation that happened prior to another past event. It can be used to explain past regrets, experiences, and situations that were true in the past but not necessarily in the present.

examples.kr: 그날까지는 그녀를 보지 않았어요, 그러나 그 전에는 수없이 많은 편지들을 썼었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunalkkajineun geunyeoreul boji anhasseoyo, geureona geu jeoneneun sueobsi maneun pyeonjideureul sseosseosseoyo.
examples.en: Until that day, I didn't see her, but before that, I had written countless letters.

examples.kr: 처음 한국에 왔을 때, 알파벳밖에 모르는 상황이었어요. 그러나 나는 알파벳을 가르치기 위해 한국어를 배웠었어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum hanguge waseul ttae, alphabetsbakke moreuneun sanghwangieosseoyo. Geureona naneun alphabeteul gareuchigi wihae hangugeoreul baeweosseosseoyo.
examples.en: When I first came to Korea, I was in a situation where I knew nothing but the alphabet. But I had learned Korean to teach the alphabet.

examples.kr: 그는 오늘 아침에 호텔로 왔었어요, 하지만 점심에는 그 학교에 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun oneul achime hotelro wasseosseoyo, hajiman jeomsimeneun geu hakyoe isseosseoyo.
examples.en: He had come to the hotel this morning, but he was at that school at lunchtime.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀에게 단지 한 번만 인사했었어요. 그 후로는 그녀를 보지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoege danji han beonman insahaesseosseoyo. Geu huroe geunyeoreul boji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I had just greeted her once. After that, I couldn't see her.

title: ~했으면 [haesseumyeon] (If it were)
short_explanation: This is used to express hypothetical condition; 'If it were', 'If it could be'.
long_explanation: '~했으면 [haesseumyeon]' is a Korean grammar structure used to express hypothetical situations or conditions in the past. It's often used to reflect wishes, or to suppose different outcomes based on past events. It's generally translated 'If it were' or 'If it could be' in English.

examples.kr: 그때 해외로 외출했으면 지금 그리움을 느끼지 않았을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geuttae haeoero oechoolhaesseumyeon jigeum geuriumeul neukkiji anhassdeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I had gone abroad at that time, I would not feel the loneliness now.

examples.kr: 답을 알았으면 시험에서 더 잘 했을 것이에요.
examples.romaji: Dabeul arasseumyeon siheomeseo deo jal haesseul geosieyo.
examples.en: If I knew the answer, I would have done better on the test.

examples.kr: 당신이 저를 그때 도와줬으면, 저는 실패하지 않았을 것이에요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini jeoreul geuttae dowajwosseumyeon, jeoneun silpaehaji anhasseul geosieyo.
examples.en: If you had helped me then, I would not have failed.

examples.kr: 그 일을 빨리 처리했으면, 지금 이 문제를 겪지 않았을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Geu ireul ppalli cheorihwasseumyeon, jigeum i munjereul gyeokji anhasseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: If I had handled that work quickly, I wouldn't be facing this problem now.

title: ~했을 때 [haesseul ttae] (When someone did)
short_explanation: Used to express the time when a particular action or event took place.
long_explanation: '~했을 때 [haesseul ttae]' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate the time when a specific action or event happened in the past. It's typically translated as 'when someone did' in English. It's utilized to connect two clauses: the first clause describes the action in the past and the second clause conveys the result or consequence of that action.
formation: Verb in past tense + 았을 때/었을 때

examples.kr: 나는 어렸을 때 가족과 많이 여행갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoryeosseul ttae gajokgwa mani yeohaenggasseoyo.
examples.en: When I was young, I used to travel a lot with my family.

examples.kr: 처음 한국어를 배웠을 때 말하기가 참 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum hangugeoreul baewosseul ttae malhagiga cham eoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: When I first learned Korean, speaking was very difficult.

examples.kr: 그가 도서관에 갔을 때 기다려야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga doseogwane gasseul ttae gidaryeoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: When he went to the library, I had to wait.

examples.kr: 당신이 울었을 때 나도 슬퍼지는 걸 알아버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Dangshini ureosseul ttae nado seulpeojineun geol arabureosseoyo.
examples.en: When you cried, I realized that I also get sad.

title: ~했을 텐데 [haesseul tende] (I think I did)
short_explanation: Used to express a strong assumption or belief about a past action.
long_explanation: '~했을 텐데' is a grammatical expression used in Korean to indicate a strong assumption or belief regarding a past action or state. The speaker believes that the action mentioned has likely occurred in the past, even though they do not have direct or definite confirmation. This grammar form conveys a sense of uncertainty combined with a high probability.

examples.kr: 나는 그 양식을 이미 제출했을 텐데 왜 다시 요구하는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geu yangsigeul imi jeculhaesseul tende wae dasi yoguhaneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I think I've already submitted that form, I don't know why they're asking for it again.

examples.kr: 그는 그 소식을 들었을 텐데 아직 반응이 없네요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geu sosigeul deureosseul tende ajik baneungi eopsneyo.
examples.en: I think he must have heard the news, but he hasn't responded yet.

examples.kr: 우리는 그 날 회의에 참석했을 텐데 이름이 명단에 없습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun geu nal hoeuie chamseokhaesseul tende ireumi myeongdane eopseumnida.
examples.en: We should've attended the meeting that day, but our names aren't on the list.

examples.kr: 그녀는 이 연락을 받았을 텐데 아직 답장이 오지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun i yeonrageul badasseul tende ajik dapjangi oji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: She should have received this message, but she hasn't replied yet.

title: ~했지만 [haetjiman] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express a contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~했지만 [haetjiman]' is a conjunctive form used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two clauses. It is often used to combine sentences or points that may initially seem consistent, but have some form of contradiction or surprising element within them. This is similar to the English conjunctions 'but' or 'however'.

examples.kr: 여행을 많이 가고 싶었지만, 시간이 없어서 못 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengeul mani gago sipeotjiman, sigani eopseoso mot gassseoyo.
examples.en: I wanted to travel a lot but I couldn't because I didn't have time.

examples.kr: 저는 공부를 열심히 했지만, 시험에서 높은 점수를 받지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbureul yeolsimhi haetjiman, siheomeseo nopeun jeomsureul batji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although I studied hard, I did not get high scores in the exam.

examples.kr: 그는 재미있는 일을 많이 하고 싶었지만, 매일밤 일해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jaemiissneun ireul mani hago sipeotjiman, maeilbam ilhaeya haesseoyo.
examples.en: He wanted to do a lot of fun things, but he had to work every night.

examples.kr: 친구들과 함께 놀고 싶었지만, 과제때문에 나갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa hamkke nolgo sipeotjiman, gwajettaemune nagal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I wanted to play with my friends, but I couldn't go out due to assignments.

title: ~혀/어/여 [hyeo/eo/yeo] (Because, so)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to indicate the reason or cause for something. It can be translated as 'because' or 'so' in English.
long_explanation: The ~혀/어/여 [hyeo/eo/yeo] ending is used in Korean grammar to denote a cause and effect relationship between two clauses. The clause that contains ~혀/어/여 indicates the reason or cause for the action or state expressed in the main clause. The form of ~혀/어/여 depends on the final syllable of the verb stem it follows: '혀' is used after a verb stem ending in '하', '어' after those ending in a vowel, and '여' after those ending in 'ㅏ' or 'ㅗ'.

examples.kr: 저는 배가 고파서 밥을 많이 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun baega gopaseo babeul manhi meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I ate a lot because I was hungry.

examples.kr: 그는 성격이 좋아서 친구가 많아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun seonggyeogi joaseo chinguga manhayo.
examples.en: He has a lot of friends because his personality is good.

examples.kr: 나는 기차가 늦어서 회사에 늦었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun gichaga neujeoseo hoesae neujeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was late to the office because the train was late.

examples.kr: 이 방이 너무 시끄러워서 공부를 할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: I bangi neomu sikkureoseo gongbureul hal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can't study because this room is too noisy.

title: ~혀/어/여야 [hyeo/eo/yeoya] (Have to)
short_explanation: Used to express necessity or obligation; 'have to', 'must'.
long_explanation: '~혀/어/여야 [hyeo/eo/yeoya]' is a Korean grammar pattern used to indicate the necessity or obligation to do something, similar to 'have to' or 'must' in English. It is usually used when the speaker wants to express that a certain action must be done in order to achieve something, or when there is a compelling need to perform the action. The ending '야' is combined with a verb stem and an auxiliary verb, depending on the verb stem's final vowel.

examples.kr: 기말고사를 위해 어려운 문제들을 많이 풀어야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Gimalgosareul wihae eoryeoun munjedeureul mani pureoya habnida.
examples.en: I have to solve many difficult problems for the final exam.

examples.kr: 오늘은 일찍 자야 내일의 피곤을 피할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun iljjik jaya naeirui pigoneul pihal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I have to go to bed early today in order to avoid fatigue tomorrow.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 달을 위해 더 많이 돈을 벌어야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon dareul wihae deo mani doneul beoreoya haeyo.
examples.en: I have to earn more money for this month.

examples.kr: 프로젝트 제출 전에 팀원들과 미팅을 하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Peurojekteu jechul jeone timweondeulgwa mitingeul hayeoya habnida.
examples.en: We have to have a meeting with team members before submitting the project.

title: ~후에 [hue] (After)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the happening of an action or event after another action or event.
long_explanation: '~후에 [hue]' is a time-related grammar point used in Korean language to denote the sequential happening of events, meaning 'after' in English. It is used to connect two different events or actions where the second event or action happens after the first event or action. The use of this grammar point emphasizes the chronology of events.

examples.kr: 저는 학교를 졸업한 후에 바로 일을 찾으러 갔어요, 다른 일이 있다고 쉴 수 있는 시간이 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoreul joleophan hue baro ireul chajeureo gasseoyo, dareun iri issgo swil su issneun sigani eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: After I graduated from school, I immediately went to find a job, I didn't have time to rest because there were other things to do.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 일어난 후에 운동을 하고 다시 집에 돌아와서 준비를 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil ileonan hue undongeul hago dasi jibe dorawaseo junbireul haeyo.
examples.en: After I wake up every day, I exercise and then go back home to get ready.

examples.kr: 밥을 먹은 후에 휴식 시간이 있어서 친구들하고 대화를 나눠요.
examples.romaji: Babeul meogeun hue hyusik sigani isseoseo chingudeulhago daehwareul nanwoyo.
examples.en: After eating, I have a rest time and have a conversation with my friends.

examples.kr: 공부를 한 후에 테스트를 볼 것이지만 그럴 시간이 많이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul han hue testeu-reur bol geosijiman geureol sigani mani eopseoyo.
examples.en: I'm going to take a test after studying, but I don't have a lot of time to do so.

title: ~(으)나 [(eu)na] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contradiction or opposition; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~(으)나 [(eu)na]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate a contrast or a contradiction between two clauses or sentences. It conveys a sense of transition from one point to another, similar to 'but' or 'however' in English. It is used to deliver a contrary opinion or fact, often giving a surprising or contradictory information.

examples.kr: 오늘은 사실 기분이 좋으나, 날씨가 너무 비올려서 좀 힘이 들어요.
examples.romaji: Oneureun sasil gibuni joeuna, nalssiga neomu biollyeoseo jom himi deureoyo.
examples.en: I actually feel good today, but the weather seems to be rainy, which is a bit draining.

examples.kr: 집에 가고 싶으나, 공부를 더 해야해서 학교에 머물러야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jibe gago sipuna, gongbureul deo haeyahaseo hakgyoe meomulleoya haeyo.
examples.en: I want to go home, but I need to study more so I have to stay at school.

examples.kr: 나는 물론 친구들도 이 영화를 볼 계획이었으나, 표가 다 매진되어서 볼 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun mullon chingudeuldo i yeonghwareul bol gyehogieosseuna, pyoga da maejindoeseo bol su eopseossseoyo.
examples.en: Of course, not only me but my friends also planned to watch this movie, but the tickets were all sold out so we couldn't watch it.

examples.kr: 숙제가 많으나, 워낙 지독하게 어려워서 정말히 어떻게 할지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sukjega manhna, wonag jidokhage eoryeowoseo jeongmalhi eotteohge halji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: There's a lot of homework, but it's so viciously hard that I really don't know what to do.

title: ~(으)ㄹ까요? [(eu)lkka yo?] (Shall we?)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to make a suggestion or proposal to do something together.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ까요?' is a grammar form in Korean which is used when someone is offering a suggestion or making a proposal. This sentence ending is used when the speaker wishes to propose something altogether with the person they're talking to. For verbs that end with a vowel, only 'ㄹ까요?' is added, if it ends a consonant, '을까요?' is used.

examples.kr: 우리 사진 찍을까요? 날씨가 좋아서 멋진 사진이 나올 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Uri sajin jjigeulkka yo? Nalssiga joaseo meongjin sajini naol geot gatayo.
examples.en: Shall we take a photo? The weather is nice, so I think we will get a great picture.

examples.kr: 점심시간에 함께 운동할까요? 몸을 움직이는 것이 건강에 좋으니까요.
examples.romaji: Jeomsimsigan-e hamkke undonghalkka yo? Momeul umjigineun geosi geongange jo-eunikka yo.
examples.en: Shall we exercise together during lunch time? Moving the body is good for health.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 영화를 볼까요? 재미있는 영화가 많이 개봉했어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumale yeonghwareul bolkka yo? Jaemiissneun yeonghwaga manh-i gaebonghaess-eoyo.
examples.en: Shall we watch a movie this weekend? There have been a lot of fun movies released.

examples.kr: 같이 커피를 마실까요? 커피를 마시면서 이야기를 나누면 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Gachi keopileul masilkka yo? Keopireul masimyeonseo iyagileul nanumyeon jo-eul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Shall we have a coffee together? I think it would be nice to have a conversation while drinking coffee.

title: ~(으)ㄹ래요 [(eu)llae yo] (I will)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when the speaker is suggesting doing something or explaining his/her intention.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ래요 [(eu)llae yo]' is a Korean grammar structure used to express the speaker's intention or decision to perform an action. It can also indicate a suggestion provided by the speaker, inviting others to join them in an action. This form is usually used in informal (or polite but casual) situations among friends, family, and people who are about the same age or younger.

examples.kr: 저녁에 같이 영화를 볼래요? 제가 좋은 영화를 찾아보았어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonyeoge gachi yeongwareul bollae yo? Jega joheun yeongwareul chajabwasseoyo.
examples.en: Do you want to watch a movie together in the evening? I have found a good movie.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으니까 외부에서 점심을 먹을래요. 신선한 공기를 즐기면서 식사할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheunikka oebueseon jeomsimeul meogeullae yo. Sinsaenghan gonggireul jeulgimyeonseo siksa hal su isseoyo.
examples.en: Since the weather is nice, I want to eat lunch outside. We can enjoy fresh air while dining.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 저와 체스를 둘래요? 제가 오랫동안 연습해 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeoge jewa cheseureul dullae yo? Jega oraesdongan yeonseuphae wasseoyo.
examples.en: Do you want to play chess with me this evening? I have been practicing for a long time.

examples.kr: 당신의 분실물을 찾을래요. 택시 드라이버에게 연락해 볼게요.
examples.romaji: Dangsinui bunsilmureul chajeullae yo. Taeksi deuraibeoege yeonlakhae bolgeyo.
examples.en: I will look for your lost item. I will try contacting the taxi driver.

title: ~(으)면서 [(eu)myeonseo] (While)
short_explanation: Used to express 'while' or 'at the same time' in Korean.
long_explanation: '~(으)면서 [(eu)myeonseo]' is used in Korean to denote simultaneous actions or states. It is similar to 'while' in English, indicating that two or more actions are happening at the same time. It can also be used to express contradictions between two clauses, akin to 'but' or 'however'., usually to express a sense of surprise or unexpected situations.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 다니면서 풀타임으로 일을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe danimyeonseo pulltaimeuro ireul hago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I'm working full time while attending school.

examples.kr: 승민은 음악을 들으면서 공부를 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Seungmin-eun eumag-eul deuleumyeonseo gongbuleul hago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Seungmin is studying while listening to music.

examples.kr: 그는 눈물을 흘리면서 웃었어요, 그의 기쁨이 넘쳐서 그랬어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun nunmureul heullimyeonseo us-eoss-eoyo, geuui gippeumi neomchyeoseo geulaess-eoyo.
examples.en: He laughed while shedding tears, because his joy was overflowing.

examples.kr: 할머니는 요리도 하면서 또 사랑방에서 얘기를 해주시는데, 나는 그게 능력이라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Halmoni-neun yori-do hamyeonseo tto sarangbang-eseo yaegi-reul haeju-sineunde, na-neun geuge neungnyeok-irago saenggag-haeyo.
examples.en: My grandma cooks and also tells stories in the living room at the same time - I think that's skill.

title: ~(으)로 [(eu)ro] (Towards, by means of)
short_explanation: This particle is used to express the direction, means or method, or the purpose of an action.
long_explanation: '~(으)로 [(eu)ro]' is a particle in Korean that can be used to express various meanings in a sentence, including direction towards which an action is made, means or method by which an action is carried out, and the purpose or intended result of an action. Depending on the context, it can be equivalent to English prepositions like 'to', 'by', 'with', 'as', or 'for'.
formation: If the preceding noun ends with a vowel, use ‘로’. If the preceding noun ends with a consonant, use ‘으로’.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 지하철로 회사에 가요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim jihacheollo hoesae gayo.
examples.en: I go to the office by subway every morning.

examples.kr: 나는 이 문제를 해결하기 위해 새로운 방법으로 시도했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun i munjeeul haegyeolhagi wihae saeroun bangbeobeuro sidohaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried a new method to solve this problem.

examples.kr: 저는 친구를 공항으로 배웠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chingureul gonghangeuro baewosseoyo.
examples.en: I took my friend to the airport.

examples.kr: 여행 계획을 세우는 것은 종이와 펜으로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng gyehoegeul seuneun geoseun jongiwa pen euro haesseoyo.
examples.en: I planned the trip with paper and pen.

title: ~(으)로서 [(eu)roseo] (As)
short_explanation: This is used to mean 'as' or 'in the capacity of'.
long_explanation: The Korean grammar point '~(으)로서 [(eu)roseo]' is used when you want to express the concept of doing something or existing in the capacity or status of something or someone. This is akin to the English preposition 'as'. The rule to remember is, if the noun ends with a consonant, we use 으로서, and if the noun ends with a vowel, we use 로서.

examples.kr: 기자로서의 역할을 최선으로 다하려고 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gijaroseo-ui yeoghaleul choeseoneuro daharyeogo noryeokhago issoyo.
examples.en: I'm trying to do my best in my role as a journalist.

examples.kr: 나는 한 학생으로서 나의 의무를 다해야 해.
examples.romaji: Naneun han haksaengeuroseo na-ui uimureul dahayeya hae.
examples.en: I, as a student, have to fulfill my duties.

examples.kr: 마지막으로 국민으로서 아주 중요한 일을 하여야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Majimag-euro gungmin-euroseo aju jungyohan il-eul hayeoya hapnida.
examples.en: Lastly, as a citizen, I have a very important task to do.

examples.kr: 어머니로서 그녀는 항상 가족을 위해 최선을 다합니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeoniroseo geunyeoneun hangsang gajogeul wihae choeseoneul dahabnida.
examples.en: As a mother, she always does her best for her family.

title: ~(으)로써 [(eu)rosseo] (By, as)
short_explanation: Used to express the means or method of something; similar to 'by', 'as', 'via' in English.
long_explanation: '~(으)로써 [(eu)rosseo]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate the method or means by which something occurs or the capacity in which a person or thing is acting. It is used when you want to put emphasis on the method, means, or capacity, not the agent or the doer of the action. It expresses the sense of 'by means of', 'with', 'as', 'via' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 이 성과를 이루기 위해 노력으로써 성공했습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i seonggwaleul irugi wihae noryeogeuroseo seonggongaessseubnida.
examples.en: I have achieved this result by means of effort.

examples.kr: 그는 시간 관리로써 스스로를 통제하는 방법을 배웠습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sigan gwonliloseo seuseuloreul tongjehaneun bangbeobeul baewassseubnida.
examples.en: He learned the method of controlling himself through time management.

examples.kr: 이 숙제는 그녀의 가르침으로써 완성했습니다.
examples.romaji: I sukjeneun geunyeoui gareuchimeuroseo wanseonghaetsseubnida.
examples.en: I have completed this homework by her teachings.

examples.kr: 감독으로써 그는 영화를 완성했습니다.
examples.romaji: Gamdogeuroseo geuneun yeonghwareul wanseonghaessseubnida.
examples.en: As a director, he has completed the film.

title: ~(으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeogo hada] (To try to)
short_explanation: This structure is commonly used to express 'trying to do' something or 'intending to' do something.
long_explanation: '~(으)려고 하다 [(eu)ryeogo hada]' is a useful grammar pattern in Korean that is used to indicate an intention or a plan to perform an action in the future. It gives a nuance similar to the English expressions 'I am going to' or 'I am planning to'. This can also be used to share one's aim or goal that they intend to achieve.
formation: Verb Stem + 려고 하다 (if the last syllable does not end in a vowel) / Verb Stem + 으려고 하다 (if the last syllable ends in a vowel)

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 더 잘하려고 하다 매일 연습을 많이 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul deo jalharyeogo hada maeil yeonseubeul manhi habnida.
examples.en: I practice every day because I am trying to improve my Korean language.

examples.kr: 우리 어머니는 맛있는 저녁 식사를 준비하려고 하다 요리공부를 합니다.
examples.romaji: Uri eomeonineun masitneun jeonyeok siksa-reul junbiharyeogo hada yorigongbu-reul habnida.
examples.en: My mother studies cooking because she's trying to prepare a delicious dinner.

examples.kr: 동생은 더 큰 키를 위해 매일 운동을 하려고 하다.
examples.romaji: Dongsaeng-eun deo keun ki-reul wihae maeil undong-eul haryeogo hada.
examples.en: My younger sibling exercises every day in an attempt to grow taller.

examples.kr: 친구가 알려준 새로운 앱을 사용하려고 하다 제 전화를 업데이트 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguga allyeojun saeroun aebeul sayongharyeogo hada je jeonhwareul eopdeiteu haessseubnida.
examples.en: I updated my phone to try the new app that my friend recommended.

title: ~(으)리라 [(eu)rira] (Probably)
short_explanation: This grammar form is used to express a supposition or assumption by the speaker, similar to 'probably' in English.
long_explanation: '~(으)리라 [(eu)rira]' is a Korean grammar form that is used when the speaker wants to make a supposition or assumption about something, similar to 'probably' in English. This form is frequently used in daily conversations and writings when the speaker has a belief about a certain outcome but isn't completely sure. Therefore, sentences that include this grammar pattern can be seen as educated guesses.
formation: Verb stem + (으)리라 (If the verb stem’s last vowel is 아/오, use 아리라. If not, use 으리라)

examples.kr: 그가 아마 내일 출근하리라 생각이 들어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ama naeil chulgeunharira saenggagi deuleoyo.
examples.en: I suppose he will probably come to work tomorrow.

examples.kr: 기말고사 성적이 좋으리라 확신이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gimalgosa seongjeogi joeurira hwaksini isseoyo.
examples.en: I am convinced that my final exam scores will probably be good.

examples.kr: 비가 오리라 생각하고 우산을 가져왔어요.
examples.romaji: Biga orira saenggakago usaneul gajyeowasseoyo.
examples.en: I brought an umbrella thinking it would probably rain.

examples.kr: 저는 회사에 빠르게 승진하리라 예상했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hoesae ppareuge seungjinharira yesanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I expected that I would probably be promoted quickly at the company.

title: ~(으)실 거예요 [(eu)sil geoyeyo] (You will probably)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express an educated guess or assumption about a future action pertaining to a third person.
long_explanation: '~(으)실 거예요 [(eu)sil geoyeyo]' is a future tense form used in the Korean language to talk about a third person's probable or expected future action or state. It is used when the speaker is assuming or making an educated guess about someone's future action based on certain information. It is also used to express a plan or intention of a third person in a polite and formal way.

examples.kr: 어머니는 내일 아침에 일찍 나가실 거예요, 미리 아침밥을 준비해 두세요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun naeil achimae iljjik nagasil geoyeyo, miri achimbabeul junbihae duseyo.
examples.en: Mother will probably leave early tomorrow morning, so prepare the breakfast in advance.

examples.kr: 선생님은 이 문제에 대해 많이 알고 계실 거예요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimeun i munjee daehae mani algo gyesil geoyeyo.
examples.en: The teacher will probably know a lot about this problem.

examples.kr: 우리 부모님은 아마 다음 주에 회사에 갈 거라고 생각하실 거예요.
examples.romaji: Uri bumonimeun ama daeum jue hoesae gal georago saenggakhasil geoyeyo.
examples.en: Our parents will probably think that they will go to the company next week.

examples.kr: 대통령님은 내년에도 여기를 방문하실 거예요.
examples.romaji: Daetongryeongnimeun naenyeonedo yeogireul bangmunhasil geoyeyo.
examples.en: The president will probably visit here next year too.

title: ~(으)면 좋겠다 [(eu)myeon jokgetda] (It would be good if)
short_explanation: Used to express a hope or wish for something to occur in the future.
long_explanation: '~(으)면 좋겠다 [(eu)myeon jokgetda]' is a structure used in Korean to articulate a hope, wish, or desire for a future event or situation. Essentially, it translates to 'it/that would be good if', indicating that the speaker would be pleased if the circumstance they mentioned comes true. It can be employed in both simple and hypothetical situations, expressing the speaker's yearning for a certain outcome.

examples.kr: 내일 날씨가 좋으면 좋겠어요, 외출 계획이 있어서 맑은 하늘이 좋겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Naeil nalssiga joh-eumyeon johgesseoyo, oe chul gye hwa gi iss-eoseo mal k-un haneul-i johgessseubnida.
examples.en: It would be good if the weather is nice tomorrow, as I have plans to go out and would like a clear sky.

examples.kr: 시험에서 잘 보면 좋겠다, 많은 노력을 들였으니까.
examples.romaji: Siheom-eseo jal bomyeon johketda, manheun noryeog-eul deulyeoss-eunikka.
examples.en: I wish I perform well in the exam, as I have put in a lot of effort.

examples.kr: 치킨을 먹으면 좋겠다, 치킨이 너무 좋아해서.
examples.romaji: Chikin-eul meok-eumyeon johketda, chikin-i neomu joahaseo.
examples.en: I wish to eat chicken, because I really like chicken.

examples.kr: 여행을 갈 수 있으면 좋겠다, 집에 갖혀 있어서 너무 지루해.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng-eul gal su iss-eumyeon johketda, jib-e gachyeo iss-eoseo neomu jiluhae.
examples.en: It would be good if I can go on a vacation, as it is so boring to be stuck at home.

title: ~(으)면서도 [(eu)myeonseodo] (While, although)
short_explanation: Used to express 'while' or 'although', indicating a situation or action that happens concurrently with another, or contrary to expectation.
long_explanation: The grammar point ~(으)면서도 [(eu)myeonseodo] is used in Korean to indicate that an event or situation is happening while another is also taking place, or when something is contrary to expectation. It can be translated as 'while' or 'although'. This form can be used with both action verbs and descriptive verbs. With this grammar pattern, you can express the continuation of two situations at the same time or describe a contrastive situation.

examples.kr: 그는 화가 나면서도 미소를 지었다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hwaga namyeonseodo misoreul jieossda.
examples.en: Although he was angry, he smiled.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아프면서도 학교에 갔다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun apeumyeonseodo hakgyoe gassda.
examples.en: Although she was sick, she went to school.

examples.kr: 비가 와도, 방송은 계속해서 진행 중이었어요.
examples.romaji: Biga wado, bangsongeun gyesokhaeseo jinhaeng jungeosseoyo.
examples.en: Although it was raining, the broadcast continued.

examples.kr: 이 어린아이는 영화를 보면서도 언제나 놀기 위한 계획을 세우고 있었다.
examples.romaji: I eoriniaeneun yeonghwareul bomyeonseodo eonjena nolgi wihan gyehoegreul seugo isseossda.
examples.en: While watching the movie, this little child was always planning to play.

title: ~(으)니까 [(eu)nikka] (Because, Since)
short_explanation: Used to express cause and effect, or to provide a reason or explanation.
long_explanation: '~(으)니까 [(eu)nikka]' is a conjunction used in Korean to express the relationship of cause and effect between two clauses, similar to 'because' or 'since' in English. It attaches to the verb stem, stating the reason why something is or will be in a certain state, or explaining the cause of an action or situation.

examples.kr: 점심 먹었으니까 지금은 배가 고프지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jomsim meogeoss-eunikka jigeum-eun baega gopeuji anh-ayo.
examples.en: Because I had lunch, I'm not hungry now.

examples.kr: 은행에 갔으니까 돈을 인출 할 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Eunhaeng-e gass-eunikka don-eul inchul hal su iss-eoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Since I went to the bank, I was able to withdraw money.

examples.kr: 조용히 공부하고 있으니까 방해하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: Joyonghi gongbuha-go iss-eunikka banghaehaji maseyo.
examples.en: I am studying quietly, so do not disturb me.

examples.kr: 비가 오고 있으니까 우산을 가져가세요.
examples.romaji: Bi-ga ogo iss-eunikka usan-eul gajyeogaseyo.
examples.en: Because it's raining, take an umbrella.

title: ~(으)다 보니 [(eu)da boni] (Seeing that, as)
short_explanation: Used to show the reason or cause of a certain result or situation based on a continuous action or state.
long_explanation: '~(으)다 보니 [(eu)da boni]' is a grammatical construct in Korean that expresses a result or condition that naturally occurred or was realized through continuous action or state. It is similar to the English expressions 'seeing that', 'as', or 'since'. It expresses an idea that one thing naturally or inevitably leads to another.

examples.kr: 빨리 왔다 보니 시작하기 전에 잠시 쉬어도 돼.
examples.romaji: Ppalli watda boni sijakhagi jeon-e jamsi swieodo dwae.
examples.en: Seeing that I've come early, it's okay to rest a bit before we start.

examples.kr: 한 달 동안 매일 운동하다 보니 체중이 좀 빠졌어요.
examples.romaji: Han dal dongan maeil undonghada boni chejungi jom ppajyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Seeing that I have exercised every day for a month, I lost some weight.

examples.kr: 꾸준히 공부하다 보니 점점 한국어가 늘어나는 것을 느꼈어요.
examples.romaji: Kkujunhi gongbuhada boni jeomjeom hanguk-eoga neuleonaneun geoseul neukkyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Seeing that I was studying regularly, I felt my Korean getting better.

examples.kr: 매일 아침 일찍 일어나다 보니 점심을 먹으면 바로 피곤해져요.
examples.romaji: Maeil achim iljjik ileonada boni jeomsimeul meogeumyeon baleo pigonhaejyeoyo.
examples.en: Seeing that I wake up early every morning, I get tired right after eating lunch.

title: ~(으)다가 [(eu)daga] (And then, but)
short_explanation: Expresses a sequence of actions or represents a contrast in situations.
long_explanation: '~(으)다가 [(eu)daga]' is a commonly used Korean grammar point that represents sequencing of actions or contrasting situations. When used in sentences, it means 'and then' or 'but' in English and signifies first one action followed by another. Also, it can be used to indicate a shift or change from the initial situation or status.
formation: Verb stem + 다가 / Verb stem + 으다가 (If the verb stem ends in a consonant)

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽다가 잠이 들어버렸어요, 그래서 마지막 부분을 읽지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaegeul ilgdaga jami deureobeoryeosseoyo, geuraeseo majimak bubuneul ilgji mothae:aess-eoyo.
examples.en: I was reading a book and then fell asleep, so I wasn't able to read the last part.

examples.kr: 우리는 영화를 보다가 갑자기 전기가 나가서 끝부분을 볼 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun yeonghwareul bodaga gapjagi jeongiga nagaseo kkeutbubuneul bol su eobseosseoyo.
examples.en: We were watching a movie but suddenly the power went out so we couldn't see the end.

examples.kr: 그는 말하다가 갑자기 웃음을 터뜨려서 모두를 놀라게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun malhadaga gapjagi useumeul teotteureoseo modureul nollage haess-eoyo.
examples.en: He was talking and then burst out laughing, surprising everyone.

examples.kr: 난 집에 가다가 친구와 우연히 만나서 함께 저녁을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Nan jibe gadaga chinguwa uyeonhi mannaseo hamkke jeonyeogeul meogeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I was on my way home and then met a friend by chance and had dinner together.

title: ~(으)던 [(eu)deon] (Who used to)
short_explanation: This is used to describe an action or state that used to exist in the past but does not exist now.
long_explanation: '~(으)던 [(eu)deon]' is a Korean grammar point used when referring back to a past state or action that has since ended. It corresponds to 'who used to' or 'that used to' in English. It looks back on something from the present perspective. It implies that the action or state was continuous or habitual in the past.

examples.kr: 나는 어릴 때 많이 울던 아이였어요. 그런데 지금은 별로 울지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eoril ttae mani uldeon aiyeosseoyo. Geureonde jigeumeun byeollo ulji anhayo.
examples.en: I used to be a child who cried a lot when I was young. But now, I hardly cry.

examples.kr: 그는 어렸을 때 언제나 사과를 좋아하던 사람이었어요. 하지만 지금은 사과를 싫어해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun eoryeosseul ttae eonjena sagwareul joahadeon saramieosseoyo. Hajiman jigeumeun sagwareul silheohaeyo.
examples.en: He was a person who always used to like apples when he was a kid. But he dislikes apples now.

examples.kr: 우리 학교에는 많은 학생들이 수학을 싫어하던 선생님이 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Uri hakgyoeneun maneun haksengdeuli suhageul silheohadeon seonsaengnim-i isseosseoyo.
examples.en: There was a teacher at our school who many students used to hate for math.

examples.kr: 그녀는 앞산에 살던 친절한 아주머니였습니다. 하지만 이젠 그녀를 볼 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun apsane saldeon chinjeolhan ajumeoniyeosseumnida. Hajiman ijen geunyeoreul bol su eobseoyo.
examples.en: She was a kind old lady who used to live in the mountainside. But now, we cannot see her anymore.

title: ~(으)려면 [(eu)ryeomyeon] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express the condition or criteria needed to realize a certain goal or result; 'in order to', 'if one wants to'.
long_explanation: '~(으)려면 [(eu)ryeomyeon]' is a grammar pattern used in Korean to set forth the conditions or criteria needed to achieve a particular outcome. It is equivalent to 'in order to' or 'if one wants to' in English. This grammar point projects a sense of prerequisite or conditionality and is generally used to emphasize that certain conditions must be met for something to happen.
formation: Verb stem + 으려면 / Verb ending in vowel + 려면

examples.kr: 한국어 TOPIK 시험에 합격하려면 많이 연습해야 합니다, 그렇지 않으면 성공할 수 없습니다.
examples.romaji: Hangugeo TOPIK siheome habgyeokharyeomyeon mani yeonseubhaeya habnida, geureohji aneumyeon seonggonghal su eopsseumnida.
examples.en: In order to pass the Korean TOPIK exam, you have to practice a lot, otherwise you can't succeed.

examples.kr: 헬스 클럽에서 몸매를 유지하려면 지속적으로 운동하고 건강한 식단을 유지해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Heulseu keulleobeseo mommaereul yujiharyeomyeon jisokjeogeuro undonghago geonganghan sigdaneul yujihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to maintain a good figure at the gym, you have to continually exercise and keep a healthy diet.

examples.kr: 이 직업을 얻으려면 이 분야에서의 경험이 필요해요, 그렇지 않으면 충분히 경쟁력이 없을 거예요.
examples.romaji: I jikeobeul eoduryeomyeon i bunyaeseoui gyeongheomi pilyohaeyo, geureohji aneumyeon chungbunhi gyeongjaengryeogi eopseul geoyeyo.
examples.en: In order to get this job, you need experience in this field, otherwise you won't be competitive enough.

examples.kr: 이런 문제를 방지하려면 좀 더 세심한 계획이 필요해요, 그렇지 않으면 같은 문제를 다시 겪을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon munje-reul bangjiharyeomyeon jom deo sesimhan gyehoeki pilyohaeyo, geureohji aneumyeon gateun munjereul dashi gyeogeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: To prevent such issues, a more meticulous plan is needed, otherwise we could face the same problems again.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 수록 [(eu)l surok] (The more)
short_explanation: Used to express an increase in degree, intensity, or extent; 'the more... the more', 'as... as possible'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 수록 [(eu)l surok]' is a pattern used to express the correlation of increase or decrease between two actions or states in Korean, similar to 'the more... the more...' in English. It indicates that the degree, intensity, or extent of one action or state increases or decreases correspondingly to that of another action or state. It is frequently utilized in sentences to express a direct proportional relationship.

examples.kr: 운동을 할수록 건강해질 수 있어서 매일 아침에 조깅하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul halsurok geonganghaejil su isseoseo maeil achime joginghago isseoyo.
examples.en: The more I exercise, the healthier I can become, so I am jogging every morning.

examples.kr: 공부를 많이 할수록 시험에서 더 좋은 점수를 얻을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Gongbureul mani halsurok siheome deo joheun jeomsureul eodeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: The more you study, the better score you can get on the exam.

examples.kr: 음식을 빨리 먹을수록 소화 장애가 더 심해질 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eumsigeul palli meogeulsurok sohwa jangaega deo simhaejil su isseoyo.
examples.en: The faster you eat, the more severe your digestive disorder can become.

examples.kr: 시간이 지날수록 그리움이 더 깊어져요.
examples.romaji: Sigani jinalsurok geuriumi deo gipeojyeoyo.
examples.en: The longer time passes, the deeper my longing becomes.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는 중 [(eu)n/neun jung] (In the middle of)
short_explanation: Used to indicate 'in the process' or 'in the middle of' certain actions or states.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는 중 [(eu)n/neun jung]' is a grammatical pattern used in Korean to express ongoing actions or statuses, much like the continuous tense in English. It is used when you want to imply that a person is in the middle of doing something or in the process of a certain state. It's often placed after a verb stem, and the form depends on whether the stem ends in a consonant (으)ㄴ 중 or a vowel 는 중.

examples.kr: 저는 지금 숙제를 하는 중이에요, 그래서 나중에 연락 드릴게요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jigeum sukjerul haneun jungieyo, geuraeseo najunge yeonrag deurilgeyo.
examples.en: I'm in the middle of doing my homework right now, so I'll contact you later.

examples.kr: 오빠는 여자친구와 전화하는 중이라서 바쁜 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oppaneun yeojachinguwa jeonhawahaneun jungiraseo bappun geot gat-ayo.
examples.en: My older brother seems to be busy as he is in the middle of a call with his girlfriend.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 계속 질문하는 중이라서, 집중이 잘 안되요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun gyesok jilmunhaneun jungiraseo, jipjungi jal andoeyo.
examples.en: My mom keeps asking questions, so I'm not able to concentrate well.

examples.kr: 그녀는 재미있는 영화를 보는 중이에요, 그래서 웃고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jaemiissneun yeonghwareul boneun jungieyo, geuraeseo utgo isseoyo.
examples.en: She is in the middle of watching an interesting movie, that's why she is laughing.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는 탓에 [(eu)n/neun tase] (Because of)
short_explanation: Used to express the cause of a negative result or situation; 'because of'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는 탓에 [(eu)n/neun tase]' is a grammar point in Korean that is used to express the cause of a negative result or situation. It is similar to 'because of' in English. This grammar point is typically used in sentences where the cause is clearly pointed out and it led to an unfavorable or undesirable outcome.

examples.kr: 나무를 너무 많이 베어서 우리 동네의 환경이 나쁜 탓에 사람들이 많이 아파요.
examples.romaji: Namureul neomu mani beoseoseo uri dongnaeui hwangyeongi nappeun tase saramdeuli mani apayo.
examples.en: Because we cut down too many trees, the poor environment in our neighborhood is causing many people to get sick.

examples.kr: 지난주에 너무 많이 먹은 탓에 이번 주에 체중이 늘었어요.
examples.romaji: Jinanju-e neomu mani meogeun tase ibeon ju-e chejungi neuleosseoyo.
examples.en: Because I ate too much last week, I gained weight this week.

examples.kr: 연습을 충분히 하지 않은 탓에 테스트에서 좋은 점수를 받지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonseubeul chungbunhi haji anheun tase testeueseojoh-eun jeomsuleul badji moshaess-eoyo.
examples.en: Because I did not practice enough, I did not receive a good score in the test.

examples.kr: 엄마가 재료를 사러 가야 했는데 막차를 놓친 탓에 오늘은 집에서 요리를 할 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jaeryoreul saleo gaya haetneunde magchaleul nohchin tase oneuleun jibeseo yorileul hal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: Because mom missed the last bus to go shopping for ingredients, we are not able to cook at home today.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는데다가 [(eu)n/neundedaga] (Moreover, additionally)
short_explanation: Used to add more information, similar to 'moreover' or 'additionally' in English.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는데다가 [(eu)n/neundedaga]' is a compound grammar form that is used to add more detailed information on top of the information already provided. It's roughly equivalent to 'moreover', 'in addition to that', 'besides', 'what's more', or 'furthermore' in English. The idea here is that whatever is described in the part with '는데다가' is an extra, additional bit of information or characteristic on top of what has been already mentioned.

examples.kr: 이 카페는 분위기도 좋은데다가 커피 맛도 훌륭해요.
examples.romaji: I kape-neun bunwigido joheunde daga keopimatdo hulryunghaeyo.
examples.en: This cafe has a good atmosphere, moreover, the coffee tastes great.

examples.kr: 그 책은 재미있는데다가 유익하기까지 해요.
examples.romaji: Geu chaeg-eun jaemissneunde daga yu-ik hakigikka jehaeyo.
examples.en: That book is not only interesting but also informative.

examples.kr: 이 핸드폰은 가격이 저렴한데다가 기능도 다양하게 있어요.
examples.romaji: I haendeupon-eun gagyeogi jeoryeomhaneunde daga gineungdo dayanghage iss-eoyo.
examples.en: This cell phone is not only cheap but also has a variety of features.

examples.kr: 그는 착한데다가 똑똑하기까지 해서, 모두가 그를 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chaghanede daga ttokttok hakigungkkaji haeseo, moduga geul-eul johah-aeyo.
examples.en: He is kind, and moreover, he is smart, so everyone likes him.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는데도 불구하고 [(eu)n/neundedo bulguhago] (Despite, in spite of)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express 'despite' or 'in spite of'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는데도 불구하고' is a long conjunction used in the Korean language to introduce a counter-expected situation or outcome despite a certain given factor or situation. This form translates to 'despite' or 'in spite of' in English. Using it, we can indicate that the event in the latter clause happens regardless of the situation described in the former clause.
formation: Adjective/Verb in past or present tense + ~(으)ㄴ/는데도 불구하고

examples.kr: 비가 오는데도 불구하고 그녀는 나가서 재미있게 놀았어요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneundedo bulguhago geunyeoneun nagaseo jaemiitge nolatseoyo.
examples.en: Despite the rain, she went out and had a good time.

examples.kr: 그는 아픈데도 불구하고 학교에 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun apeundedo bulguhago hakgyoe gasseoyo.
examples.en: Despite being sick, he went to school.

examples.kr: 원하는 결과를 얻지 못한데도 불구하고 우리는 계속 노력했어요.
examples.romaji: Wonhaneun gyeolgwareul eodji mothanedo bulguhago urineun gyesok noryeokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Despite not getting the results we wanted, we continued to make efforts.

examples.kr: 시험이 어려운데도 불구하고 그는 잘 했어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomi eoryeounnedo bulguhago geuneun jal haesseoyo.
examples.en: Despite the exam being difficult, he did well.

title: ~(으)ㄴ/는지 모르겠다 [(eu)n/neunji moreugessda] (I'm not sure if)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or a lack of confidence about something; 'I'm not sure if'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄴ/는지 모르겠다 [(eu)n/neunji moreugessda]' is a grammar structure which is used when the speaker is uncertain, unsure, unclear about something, or has a hazy knowledge of the matter being expressed. This grammar structure in Korean literally translates into English as 'I'm not sure if' or 'I don't know if'. The use of this structure highly depends on the ending of the verb/adjective.

examples.kr: 저는 장소를 정확히 기억하며 나갔는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jangsoreul jeonghwakhage gieokhamyeo nagassneunji moreugessyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I remembered the place correctly.

examples.kr: 그가 아직도 나를 사랑하는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ajikdo nareul saranghaneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if he still loves me.

examples.kr: 비가 왔었는지 모르겠는데, 여기 젖어있어요.
examples.romaji: Biga wassneunji moreugneunde, yeogi jeojeoisseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if it rained, but it's wet here.

examples.kr: 내일 학교에 갈 수 있는지 모르겠어요, 몸이 좀 아파요.
examples.romaji: Naeil hakgyoe gal su issneunji moreugesseoyo, momi jom apayo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I can go to school tomorrow, I'm a bit sick.

title: ~(으)려는 참이다 [(eu)ryeoneun chamida] (I really want to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used when the speaker expresses a strong desire or intention to do something and is often used when expressing feelings of frustration at not being able to do what one wants.
long_explanation: '~(으)려는 참이다' in Korean grammar is utilized when expressing one's strong desire or intention towards some action, especially used when the speaker is feeling a sense of frustration of not being able to do the action desired. It can be translated as 'I really want to…', 'I am dying to…'.  It is generally used for showing your strong intent or desire which you had to suppress for some reasons.

examples.kr: 이 사람, 뭐라고 할려는 참이다. 그런데 말을 할 수가 없었다.
examples.romaji: I saram, mworageo halleoneun chaminida. Geureonde maleul hal suga eopseotda.
examples.en: I really wanted to say something to this person. But I couldn't say anything.

examples.kr: 반말할려는 참이었지만 그를 존경해서 말았다.
examples.romaji: Banmalharyeoneun chamyeotjiman geureul johgyeonghaeseo maratda.
examples.en: I really wanted to speak informally, but I held back out of respect for him.

examples.kr: 야외에서 놀려는 참이지만 날씨가 너무 나빠서 할 수 없었다.
examples.romaji: Yawoeseo nollyeoneun chamijiman nalssiga nomu napaseo hal su eopsotda.
examples.en: I really wanted to play outside, but I couldn't because the weather was too bad.

examples.kr: 그 영화를 볼려는 참이었지만 표가 매진이라 보지 못했다.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaleul boryeoneun chamyeotjiman pyoga maejinira boji motaetda.
examples.en: I really wanted to watch that movie, but I couldn't because the tickets were sold out.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 것 같다 [(eu)l geot gatda] (It seems like)
short_explanation: This grammar is used to express a guess, assumption, or prediction.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 것 같다 [(eu)l geot gatda]' is used in Korean grammar to express that something seems like it would, could, or should be a certain way. It is a way of expressing a guess, assumption, or prediction, based on the available information. Whether you use 으 or not depends on the vowel in the final syllable of the preceding word. If the last syllable ends with a vowel, you drop the 으. If it ends with a consonant, you keep the 으.
formation: Verb stem + (으)ㄹ 것 같다 OR Adjective stem + (으)ㄹ 것 같다

examples.kr: 내일은 비가 올 것 같아요, 그래서 우산을 가져와야 할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun biga ol geot gatayo, geuraeseo usaneul gayowaya hal geot gatayo.
examples.en: It seems like it will rain tomorrow, so it seems like you should bring an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그녀는 행복 할 것 같아요, 왜냐하면 그녀의 드림팀에 합류했으니까요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun haengbok hal geot gatayo, waenyahamyeon geunyeoui deurimtim-e habryuhaesseunikka yo.
examples.en: It seems like she will be happy, because she has joined her dream team.

examples.kr: 이 지도를 보면 우리가 길을 잃을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I jidoreul bomyeon uriga gireul ilheul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Looking at this map, it seems like we will lose our way.

examples.kr: 이 제품의 인기가 높을 것 같아요, 왜냐하면 기능이 매우 우수하니까요.
examples.romaji: I jepumui inki-ga nop-eul geot gatayo, waenyahamyeon gineungi maeu usuhago iss-eunikka yo.
examples.en: It seems like this product will be popular because it has excellent features.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 것이다 [(eu)l geosida] (Will likely)
short_explanation: Used to express probability, anticipation, or plan for the future; 'will likely', 'suppose to', 'plan to'.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 것이다 [(eu)l geosida]' is a grammar point used in Korean to indicate the speaker's prediction, expectation, or plan regarding the future. It is similar to expressing 'will', or 'is going to' in English. The speaker uses this form when they are relatively certain about what will happen, or what they plan to do in the future.
formation: Verb stem + ㄹ 것이다 (If the verb stem's last syllable ends with a vowel) / Verb stem + 을 것이다 (If the verb stem's last syllable ends with a consonant)

examples.kr: 내일은 날씨가 좋을 것이다, 그래서 다들 야외에서 시간을 보내려고 할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Naeireun nalssiga joheul geosida, geuraeseo dadeul yaoeseo siganeul bonaeryeogo hal geosida.
examples.en: The weather will likely be good tomorrow, so everyone will probably plan to spend time outdoors.

examples.kr: 저는 내년에 대학교를 졸업할 것이다, 그리고 취업을 준비할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naenyeone daehakgyoreul joleophal geosida, geurigo chwieobeul junbihal geosida.
examples.en: I will likely graduate from university next year, and I will plan to prepare for employment.

examples.kr: 우리는 이번 주말에 캠핑을 갈 것이다, 그래서 캠핑용품을 살 것이다.
examples.romaji: Urineun ibeon jumale kaempingeul gal geosida, geuraeseo kaempingyongpumeul sal geosida.
examples.en: We will likely go camping this weekend, so we will plan to buy camping gear.

examples.kr: 그녀는 피아노 연습을 많이 하고 있으니까, 곧 잘 칠 것이다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun piano yeonseubeul manhi hago isseunikka, got jal chil geosida.
examples.en: As she is practicing the piano a lot, she will likely play well soon.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 [(eu)l ppunman anira] (Not only... but also...)
short_explanation: Used to express the concept of 'not only..., but also...', meaning that there is not just the first thing, but also the second.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 [(eu)l ppunman anira]' is a Korean grammar pattern used to express the idea of 'not only this, but also that'. The construction helps to emphasize two or more actions or situations that are true. It's used to introduce a new piece of information that adds to, rather than contradicts, the previous statement. Note also that the verb or adjective that follows this pattern can be of either positive or negative meaning.

examples.kr: 그는 일 잘하는 뿐만 아니라, 창조성까지 있어요, 그래서 모두에게 인정을 받았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun il jalhaneun ppunman anira, changjoseongkkaji isseoyo, geuraeseo modeuege injongeul badasseoyo.
examples.en: Not only does he work well, but he also has creativity, so he received recognition from everyone.

examples.kr: 이 레스토랑은 맛있는 음식을 제공하는 뿐만 아니라 훌륭한 서비스도 제공해요.
examples.romaji: I reseutorangeun masissneun eumsigeul jegonghaneun ppunman anira hullyunghan seobiseudo jegonghaeyo.
examples.en: This restaurant not only provides delicious food, but also provides excellent service.

examples.kr: 그녀는 영어를 잘하는 뿐만 아니라 중국어, 일본어도 유창해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-neun yeong-eo-reul jal-haneun ppunman anira jung-gug-eo, ilbon-eodo yuchanghaeyo.
examples.en: Not only is she fluent in English, but she also speaks Chinese and Japanese fluently.

examples.kr: 지민 씨는 요리를 잘하는 뿐만 아니라 정말 멋진 사진을 찍을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jimin ssi-neun yori-reul jal-haneun ppunman anira jeongmal meot-jin sajing-eul jjik-eul su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Not only can Jimin cook well, but he can also take really amazing photos.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 뿐이다 [(eu)l ppunida] (Only, just)
short_explanation: Used to express 'only' or 'just'. Often used to emphasize the sole action or state.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 뿐이다 [(eu)l ppunida]' is a commonly used grammar point in Korean to stress on an action or state being the only one or just. This pattern is generally used in situations where the speaker intends to emphasize a certain condition or fact as the only existing one. The conjugation depends on the final vowel of the verb stem, using '을 뿐이다' after a verb stem ending in a consonant and 'ㄹ 뿐이다' after a verb stem ending in a vowel.

examples.kr: 그녀는 말할 뿐이지, 실제로 행동하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun malhal ppuniji, siljero haengdonghaji anhayo.
examples.en: She only talks, she doesn't actually act.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀에게 웃을 뿐이다, 실제로 어떠한 대화도 하지 않았어.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoege useul ppunida, siljero eotteohan daehwado haji anhass-eo.
examples.en: I just smiled at her, I haven't actually had any conversation.

examples.kr: 아버지는 손님들과 대화할 뿐이지, 실제로 집안일을 도와주지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Abeojineun sonnimdeulgwa daehwahal ppuniji, siljero jib-an-il-eul dowajujianhayo.
examples.en: Father only converses with the guests, he doesn't actually help with housework.

examples.kr: 그들은 영화를 보러 갈 뿐이다, 실제로 영화에 대해 이야기하지 않아.
examples.romaji: Geudeuleun yeonghwa le boreo gal ppunida, siljelo yeonghwa-e daehae iyagihaji anha.
examples.en: They're just going to watch a movie, they don't actually talk about the movie.

title: ~(으)ㄹ게요 [(eu)lgeyo] (I will, in the future)
short_explanation: Used to express an intention or promise about the future, with a nuance of the speaker’s determination.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ게요 [(eu)lgeyo]' is a polite and commonly used form to show the speaker's intention, promise or plan to do something in the future. It is bonded to the stem of the verb to develop a future tense expression. It mainly conveys the speaker's strong determination to carry out the action. If a verb stem’s final syllable contains 아/오, 'ㄹ게요' is used. For all other vowel endings and consonant endings, use '을게요'. Participles, as opposed to verbs or adjectives, cannot be used with this form.
formation: Verb stem + ~(으)ㄹ게요 -> Use '을게요' for stems ending in vowels other than '아' or '오' or after consonants. Use 'ㄹ게요' for stems ending in '아' or '오'.

examples.kr: 제가 직접 전화해서 진행 상황을 알려 드릴게요.
examples.romaji: Jega jigjeop jeonhwahae seojin tae ireum sangeul allyeo deurilgeyo.
examples.en: I will call personally to let you know the progress.

examples.kr: 이 짐은 제가 갖고 갈게요, 너무 무거우니까 걱정하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: I jim eun je ga gotgo galgeyo, neomu mugeouni kka geokjeong haji mase yo.
examples.en: I will carry this luggage, don't worry because it's too heavy.

examples.kr: 과제를 내일까지 다 끝내고 보고서도 쓸게요.
examples.romaji: gwaje reul naeil kkaji da ggeut naego bogoseo do seulgeyo.
examples.en: I will finish all the tasks by tomorrow and also write the report.

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁에 모두 모이면 제가 음식을 만들어서 가져올게요.
examples.romaji: oneul jeonyeok e modu moimyeon je ga eumsik eul mandeuleoseo gajyeo olgeyo.
examples.en: When we all gather tonight, I will make and bring the food.

title: ~(으)ㄹ게 [(eu)lge] (I will, in the future)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that the speaker will do something in the future. It can also be used to suggest one's intention or promise.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ게 [(eu)lge]' is a future tense ending in Korean that indicates the speaker's intention or promise to take a future action. It's commonly used in casual conversations among friends or individuals of similar age or status. It can also be used to express a decision that the speaker has made or to promise something to the listener.
formation: Verb stem + 으ㄹ게(If the verb stem ends with a consonant)/ㄹ게 (if the verb stem ends with a vowel)

examples.kr: 저는 내일부터 다이어트할게요, 그래서 오늘은 맛있는 음식을 마지막으로 먹을게요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naeilbuteo daieoteuteulgeyo, geuraeseo oneuleun masissneun eumsigeul majimageuro meogeulgeyo.
examples.en: I will start dieting from tomorrow, so I will eat delicious food for the last time today.

examples.kr: 너무 걱정하지 마세요, 저는 한국어 공부를 열심히 할게요.
examples.romaji: Neomu geokjeonghaji maseyo, jeoneun hangugeo gongbureul yeolsimhi halgeyo.
examples.en: Don't worry too much, I will study Korean diligently.

examples.kr: 미안해요, 지금부터 절대 늦지 않을게요.
examples.romaji: Mianhaeyo, jigeumbuteo jeoldae neutji anheulgeyo.
examples.en: I'm sorry, from now on I definitely won't be late.

examples.kr: 방 청소를 안 했어? 괜찮아, 나중에 제가 할게요.
examples.romaji: Bang cheongsoeul an haesseo? Gwenchana, najunge jega halgeyo.
examples.en: Didn't you clean the room? It's okay, I will do it later.

title: ~(으)ㄹ래 [(eu)llae] (I want to)
short_explanation: Used to express that the speaker wants to do something.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ래 [(eu)llae]' is a Korean language grammar that is used when the speaker want to do something or suggest to do something, depending on the context. It is attached to the stem of the verb. The usage can differ with regards to formality, subject number, and the overall context of the sentence. It's equal to 'I want to ~' in English and is expressed in the informal tone.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 저녁에 바베큐를 먹을래, 체고하러 가고 싶어서.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul jeonyeoge babekyureul meogeullae, chegohareo gago sipheoseo.
examples.en: I want to have BBQ for dinner today, because I want to go to a steakhouse.

examples.kr: 내일 친구들과 함께 영화를 볼래, 그 거 좋아하니까.
examples.romaji: Naeil chingudeulgwa hamkke yeonghwareul bollae, geu geo joahanikka.
examples.en: I want to watch a movie with my friends tomorrow, because I like it.

examples.kr: 우리 주말에 소풍 갈래? 날씨가 좋을 거니까.
examples.romaji: Uri jumal-e sopung gallae? Nalssiga joeul geonikka.
examples.en: Do we want to go for a picnic on the weekend? Because the weather will be good.

examples.kr: 나는 새로운 취미를 찾을래, 지금까지의 취미가 지루해져서.
examples.romaji: Naneun saeroun chwimireul chajeullae, jigeumkkajiui chwimiga jiruhaejyeoseo.
examples.en: I want to find a new hobby, because my current hobby has become boring.

title: ~(으)ㄹ라고 [(eu)llago] (Intend to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express someone's intention to do something.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ라고 [(eu)llago]' is a Korean grammar point used to express a person's intention, plan, or determination to do something. It can be attached to the verb stem. When the verb stem ends with a vowel or a consonant 'ㄹ', we use 'ㄹ라고', but if the verb stem ends with any other consonant, we use '을라고'. Note that we use this grammar point when the speaker wants to express or report someone's intentions, whether it's his/her own or someone else’s.
formation: Verb stem + ㄹ라고 OR Verb stem + 을라고

examples.kr: 그는 내일 아침에 일찍 일어날라고 알람 시계를 설정했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun naeil achime iljjik ireonallago allam sigeireul seoltukhaessseubnida.
examples.en: He set the alarm clock because he intends to wake up early tomorrow morning.

examples.kr: 지민이는 축구 대회에서 우승하려고 매일 연습하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jiminieun chukgu daehoeeseo useungharyeogo maeil yeonseuphago isseoyo.
examples.en: Jimin is practicing every day because he intends to win the soccer tournament.

examples.kr: 서연이는 결혼할라고 집을 구입할 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Seoyeonineun gyeolhonhallago jibeul guiphal gyehoegeyo.
examples.en: Seoyeon plans to buy a house because she intends to get married.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 달에 새 차를 살라고 돈을 저축하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon dare sae chareul sallago doneul jeochukhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I am saving money because I intend to buy a new car this month.

title: ~(으)ㄹ 테니까 [(eu)l tenikka] (Since I assume)
short_explanation: This pattern '(으)ㄹ 테니까' is used when speaker makes guess or assumption and provides advice or suggestion based on that assumption.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ 테니까 [(eu)l tenikka]' is a Korean grammar point used to make assumptions about a situation or event based on the speaker's personal observations, beliefs, or predictions. Then, it shows the speaker's advice, suggestion, or response based on this assumption. The pattern can be used in future tense situations and generally indicates a higher degree of certainty.

examples.kr: 너무 늦어지ㄹ 테니까 이제 집에 가는 것이 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu neujeojil tenikka ije jibe ganeun geosi jotgesseoyo.
examples.en: You should probably go home now since it's going to get too late.

examples.kr: 비가 올 테니까 우산을 가져가세요.
examples.romaji: Biga ol tenikka usaneul gajyeogaseyo.
examples.en: Take an umbrella because it's going to rain.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있을 테니까 오늘 밤은 공부하는 것이 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseul tenikka oneul bameun gongbuhaneun geosi jotgesseoyo.
examples.en: Since there's a test tomorrow, it would be good to study tonight.

examples.kr: 그는 이미 알고 있을 테니까 걱정하지 마세요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun imi algo isseul tenikka geokjeonghaji maseyo.
examples.en: Don't worry because he probably already knows.

title: ~(으)ㄹ지라도 [(eu)ljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning of 'even if'; it emphasizes the condition or situation regardless of its result or consequence.
long_explanation: '~(으)ㄹ지라도 [(eu)ljirado]' is a complex suffix used in Korean to signify 'even if' or 'although'.
