It is commonly used to mention a hypothetical scenario or condition, despite the potential negative or undesired outcome. This form shows that even in the worst case or scenario, the speaker will not change their decision, action, or thought. This emphasizes the speaker's determination or resolution.
formation: Verb Stem + 으ㄹ지라도 / Verb Stem + ㄹ지라도

examples.kr: 이 일이 얼마나 어려울지라도, 저는 반드시 해내겠어요.
examples.romaji: I iri eolmana eoryeouljirado, jeoneun bandeusi haenaegesseoyo.
examples.en: No matter how difficult this task may be, I will definitely finish it.

examples.kr: 자고 싶을지라도, 다가오는 시험 때문에 밤새 공부해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jago sipeuljirado, dagaoneun siheom ttaemune bamsae gongbuhaya haeyo.
examples.en: Even though I want to sleep, I have to study all night because of the upcoming exam.

examples.kr: 비가 오지 않을지라도, 우산을 항상 가지고 다녀야 해요.
examples.romaji: Biga oji anheuljirado, usaneul hangsang gajigo danyeoya haeyo.
examples.en: Even if it doesn't rain, you should always carry an umbrella.

examples.kr: 날씨가 추울지라도, 저는 언제나 아이스크림을 먹고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga chuuljirado, jeoneun eonjena aiseukeurimeul meokgo sipeoyo.
examples.en: Even if the weather is cold, I always want to eat ice cream.

title: ~(으)면서도 [(eu)myeonseodo] (While, although)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'While', 'although'.
long_explanation: '~(으)면서도 [(eu)myeonseodo]' is a conjunction used in Korean to express situations where the preceding and following clauses contradict each other or have unexpected results. In English, this would be similar to 'while' or 'although'. It is used to express the concurrent realization of two contrasting actions or situations.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아프면서도 일을 계속 했습니다. 아픔을 거뜬히 이겨내고 일을 마무리했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun apeumyeonseodo ireul gyesok haetsseumnida. Apeumeul geotteunhi igyeonaego ileul mamurihaetseumnida.
examples.en: Although she was sick, she continued to work. She overcame the pain and finished her work.

examples.kr: 비가 오면서도 이 축제는 계속되었습니다. 모두들 즐거움에 흠뻑 빠져들었습니다.
examples.romaji: Biga omyeonseodo i chukjeneun gyesokdoeeotsseumnida. Modudeul jeulgeoume heumppok ppajyeodeureotsseumnida.
examples.en: Even though it was raining, the festival continued. Everyone was fully immersed in the fun.

examples.kr: 그는 실수를 하면서도 끝까지 이겨냈습니다. 그의 집중력과 끈기가 대단했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun silsureul hamyeonseodo ggeutkkaji igyeonaetsseumnida. Geuui jipunglyeokgwa ggeungiga daedanhaetsseumnida.
examples.en: Even though he made a mistake, he succeeded to the end. His concentration and perseverance were great.

examples.kr: 식사를 다하면서도 배가 고픈 것 같았습니다. 너무 많이 달려서 그런 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Sigsareul dahamyeonseodo baega gopeun geot gatatsseumnida. Neomu mani dallyeoseo geureon geot gatayo.
examples.en: Although I had finished eating, I felt hungry. I think it's because I ran so much.

title: ~(으)시면 [(eu)simyeon] (If you)
short_explanation: Used to express a condition or an assumption; 'if you' or 'when'.
long_explanation: '~(으)시면 [(eu)simyeon]' is a grammar point in Korean used to express a hypothetical situation or a condition. It falls under the broad 'if' conditional conjugation in Korean. It is used to express a polite form of 'if you' or 'when'. It involves the subject-action-object pattern where the action or the verb are conjugated accordingly followed by 시면 to form a conditional situation or proposal.

examples.kr: 편하시면 오늘 저녁에 저에게 전화하시는 것 어때요?
examples.romaji: Pyeonhasimyeon oneul jeonyeoge jeoege jeonhwahasineun geot eoddaeyo?
examples.en: If you're free, how about calling me tonight?

examples.kr: 수업이 끝나시면 자기소개를 시작해 주시면 감사하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Sueobi ggeut nasimyeon jaki sogae reul si jakhae jusimyeon gamsahabnida.
examples.en: I would appreciate it if you could start self-introduction when the class is over.

examples.kr: 가능하시면, 내일 회의에 참석하실 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Ganeung hasimyeon, naeil hoeuie chamseokhasil su isseulkka yo?
examples.en: If it's possible, could you attend the meeting tomorrow?

examples.kr: 시간 나시면 사진 몇장을 보여주시면 감사할게요.
examples.romaji: Siganna simyeon sajin myeot jang eul boyeo jusimyeon gamsahalggeyo.
examples.en: If you have time, I would appreciate if you could show me a few photos.

title: ~(으)시겠어요 [(eu)sigesseoyo] (You will probably)
short_explanation: Used to express probability or expectation; 'you will probably'.
long_explanation: '~(으)시겠어요 [(eu)sigesseoyo]' is a grammar point in Korean that engenders the speaker's perception of the listener's probable action or state in the near future. The speaker uses this form when he/she anticipates or predicts what the listener will do or feel, incorporating a sense of respect or politeness toward the listener. It is frequently used in formal or polite settings.

examples.kr: 날씨가 꽤 춥습니다, 당신은 아마도 목도리를 두르시겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga kkwae chubseubnida, dangsineun amado mokdorireul dureusigesseoyo.
examples.en: The weather is quite cold, you will probably wear a scarf.

examples.kr: 정말 바쁜 하루였죠, 피곤하시겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeongmal bappeun haruyeossjyo, pigonhasigesseoyo.
examples.en: It was a really busy day, you must be tired.

examples.kr: 이 분량의 일을 보니, 당신은 아마도 주말동안 일하시겠어요.
examples.romaji: I bunryangui ireul boni, dangsineun amado jumaldongan ilhasigesseoyo.
examples.en: Considering the amount of work, you will probably work over the weekend.

examples.kr: 날씨가 이렇게 더우니, 소프트드링크를 좋아하시겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga ireohge deouni, sopeuteudeuringkeureul joahasigesseoyo.
examples.en: The weather is so hot, you would probably like a soft drink.

title: ~(으)시다 [(eu)sida] (Let's)
short_explanation: This grammar form is used to propose or suggest an activity with 'let's'.
long_explanation: '~(으)시다 [(eu)sida]' is a grammar point that suggests a certain action to the audience. It can be used when the speaker suggests or proposes to do something together with one or more people. The use of this form expresses the idea of 'Let's do something' in English. Its usage is governed by the final vowel of the preceding syllable, using '으시다' with verb stems ending in a consonant and '시다' with those ending in a vowel.
formation: Verb stem + 시다 (if verb stem ends in a vowel) / Verb stem + 으시다 (if verb stem ends in a consonant)

examples.kr: 오늘 저녁 식당에서 저녁을 먹으시다, 다른 모든 일들은 잊어버려요.
examples.romaji: Oneul jeonyeok sikdangeseo jeonyeogeul meogeusida, dareun modeun ildeureun ijeobeoryeoyo.
examples.en: Let's eat dinner at a restaurant tonight, forget about everything else.

examples.kr: 우리 함께 산책하시다, 우리 모두에게 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Uri hamkke sanchaekhasida, uri modeuege joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: Let's take a walk together, it seems like it will be good for all of us.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 함께 해결하시다, 함께하면 더 쉬울 거예요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul hamkke haegyeolhasida, hamkkemyeon deo swil geoyeyo.
examples.en: Let's solve this problem together, it will be easier if we do it together.

examples.kr: 모두가 같이 여행 가시다, 같이 가면 더 즐거울 거예요.
examples.romaji: Moduga gachi yeohaeng gasida, gachi gamyeon deo jeulgeoul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Let's all go on a trip together, it will be more fun if we go together.

title: ~(으)십시오 [(eu)sipsio] (Please)
short_explanation: Used to express polite requests or commands; 'please'.
long_explanation: '~(으)십시오 [(eu)sipsio]' is a sentence ending that is used in Korean language to make a polite request or to give a polite command. It is considered a high formality level of speaking, and is often used in formal situations, such as addressing superiors or strangers. It's generally used with verbs and it changes slightly based on the final vowel of the verb stem.
formation: Verb stem + 으십시오 (if the verb stem ends with a consonant) | Verb stem + 십시오 (if the verb stem ends with a vowel)

examples.kr: 한 번 다시 생각해보십시오, 아마 그것이 옳은 선택일 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Han beon dasi saenggakhaebosipsio, ama geugeosi olheun seontaegil geosibnida.
examples.en: Please think it over again, it might be the right choice.

examples.kr: 여기 앉으십시오, 저는 당신에게 말할 것이 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Yeogi anjeusipsio, jeoneun dangshinege malhal geosi itsseumnida.
examples.en: Please sit here, I have something to tell you.

examples.kr: 집에 오셨다면, 먼저 손을 씻으십시오.
examples.romaji: Jibe osyeotdamyeon, meonjeo soneul sseusipsio.
examples.en: If you have come home, please wash your hands first.

examples.kr: 궁금증이 있다면 그 질문을 이제 물어보십시오.
examples.romaji: Gunggeumjeungi itsdamyeon geu jilmuneul ije mureobosipsio.
examples.en: If you have any queries, please ask your question now.
